      Koren, K.; Salinas, N. K. G.; Santella, M.; Moshammere, M.; Muller, M. C.; Dmitriev, R. I.; Borisov, S. M.; Kuhl, M.; Laursen, B. W. Evaluation of Ebselen-azadioxatriangulenium as redox-sensitive fluorescent intracellular probe and as indicator within a planar redox optode.       [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      60
      Evaluation of Ebselen-azadioxatriangulenium as redox-sensitive fluorescent intracellular probe and as indicator within a planar redox optode
      Koren, Klaus; Gravesen Salinas, Nina Katharina; Santella, Marco; Mosshammer, Maria; Muller, Marie-Caroline; Dmitriev, Ruslan I.; Borisov, Sergey M.; Kuhl, Michael; Laursen, Bo W.
      Dyes and Pigments (2020), 173 (), 107866CODEN: DYPIDX; ISSN:0143-7208. (Elsevier Ltd.)
      Redox homeostasis is essential for cellular survival and is therefore tightly regulated. Visualizing changes in the local redox state is essential for detecting oxidative stress, esp. with the help of red, long emission lifetime probes. The authors synthesized a new reversible, redox-sensitive fluorescent probe, ebselen-azadioxatriangulenium (Ebselen-ADOTA), and characterized its potential use for intra- and extracellular redox sensing. The probe consists of a photostable triangulenium-based fluorophore (emission max. at 564 nm) modulated by a redox-active ebselen motif. The reduced form only shows around 1/10 of the emission intensity of the oxidized form. The Ebselen-ADOTA probe exhibited reversible oxidn. and redn. in soln. under extracellular conditions. In addn., Ebselen-ADOTA can visualize an increase in oxidative stress within anaerobic bacteria when exposing them to air, the probe did not readily respond to changes in the redox environment inside mammalian cells, probably due to unfavorable localization, aggregation or binding to cysteine contg. proteins. When incorporated inside a polymer matrix (hydrogel D4 mixed with poly(acrylic acid)), the probe showed a rapid and fully reversible response to redox changes, thus enabling the prepn. of a redox-sensitive optode.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1MXitVGmtbvE&md5=7c50f6688cf275d68c3a46f38017cd7b
      open URL

      64
      Unraveling peroxynitrite formation in biological systems
      Radi, R.; Peluffo, G.; Alvarez, M. N.; Naviliat, M.; Cayota, A.
      Free Radical Biology & Medicine (2001), 30 (5), 463-488CODEN: FRBMEH; ISSN:0891-5849. (Elsevier Science Inc.)
      A review with 200 refs. Peroxynitrite promotes oxidative damage and is implicated in the pathophysiol. of various diseases that involve accelerated rates of nitric oxide and superoxide formation. The unambiguous detection of peroxynitrite in biol. systems is, however, difficult due to the combination of a short biol. half-life, limited diffusion, multiple target mol. reactions, and participation of alternative oxidn./nitration pathways. In this review, the authors provide the conceptual framework and a comprehensive anal. of the current exptl. strategies that can serve to unequivocally define the existence and quantitation of peroxynitrite in biol. systems of different levels of organization and complexity.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3MXht1Oqu70%253D&md5=1cad918f5376567591f80e1d31e4a9db

      Ferrer-Sueta, G.; Radi, R. Chemical biology of peroxynitrite: Kinetics, diffusion, and radicals. ACS Chem. Biol. 2009, 4, 161â 177,  DOI: 10.1021/cb800279q
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      65
      Chemical Biology of Peroxynitrite: Kinetics, Diffusion, and Radicals
      Ferrer-Sueta, Gerardo; Radi, Rafael
      ACS Chemical Biology (2009), 4 (3), 161-177CODEN: ACBCCT; ISSN:1554-8929. (American Chemical Society)
      A review. Peroxynitrite is formed by the very fast reaction of nitric oxide and superoxide radicals, a reaction that kinetically competes with other routes that chem. consume or phys. sequester the reagents. It can behave either as an endogenous cytotoxin toward host tissues or a cytotoxic effector mol. against invading pathogens, depending on the cellular source and pathophysiol. setting. Peroxynitrite is in itself very reactive against a few specific targets that range from efficient detoxification systems, such as peroxiredoxins, to reactions eventually leading to enhanced radical formation (e.g., nitrogen dioxide and carbonate radicals), such as the reaction with carbon dioxide. Thus, the chem. biol. of peroxynitrite is dictated by the chem. kinetics of its formation and decay and by the diffusion across membranes of the species involved, including peroxynitrite itself. On the other hand, most durable traces of peroxynitrite passing (such as 3-nitrotyrosine) are derived from radicals formed from peroxynitrite by routes that represent extremely low-yield processes but that have potentially crit. biol. consequences. Here, we have reviewed the chem. kinetics of peroxynitrite as a biochem. transient species in order to est. its rates of formation and decay and then its steady-state concn. in different intra- or extracellular compartments, trying to provide a quant. basis for its reactivity; addnl., we have considered diffusion across membranes to locate its possible effects. Finally, we have assessed the most successful attempts to intercept peroxynitrite by pharmacol. intervention in their potential to increment the existing biol. defenses that routinely deal with this cytotoxin.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXislOisbg%253D&md5=ff2d50363797e63f00c0e5e9b5a6cbc8
      open URL
    66. 66
      Pacher, P.; Beckman, J. S.; Liaudet, L. Nitric oxide and peroxynitrite in health and disease. Physiol. Rev. 2007, 87, 315â 428,  DOI: 10.1152/physrev.00029.2006
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      66
      Nitric oxide and peroxynitrite in health and disease
      Pacher, Pal; Beckman, Joseph S.; Liaudet, Lucas
      Physiological Reviews (2007), 87 (1), 315-424CODEN: PHREA7; ISSN:0031-9333. (American Physiological Society)
      A review. The discovery that mammalian cells have the ability to synthesize the free radical nitric oxide (NO) has stimulated an extraordinary impetus for scientific research in all the fields of biol. and medicine. Since its early description as an endothelial-derived relaxing factor, NO has emerged as a fundamental signaling device regulating virtually every crit. cellular function, as well as a potent mediator of cellular damage in a wide range of conditions. Recent evidence indicates that most of the cytotoxicity attributed to NO is rather due to peroxynitrite, produced from the diffusion-controlled reaction between NO and another free radical, the superoxide anion. Peroxynitrite interacts with lipids, DNA, and proteins via direct oxidative reactions or via indirect, radical-mediated mechanisms. These reactions trigger cellular responses ranging from subtle modulations of cell signaling to overwhelming oxidative injury, committing cells to necrosis or apoptosis. In vivo, peroxynitrite generation represents a crucial pathogenic mechanism in conditions such as stroke, myocardial infarction, chronic heart failure, diabetes, circulatory shock, chronic inflammatory diseases, cancer, and neurodegenerative disorders. Hence, novel pharmacol. strategies aimed at removing peroxynitrite might represent powerful therapeutic tools in the future. Evidence supporting these novel roles of NO and peroxynitrite is presented in detail in this review.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2sXitVagsr8%253D&md5=43534aa55fe52c09a2c19d04e8a652dd
      open URL

      SzabÃ³, C.; Ischiropoulos, H.; Radi, R. Peroxynitrite: biochemistry, pathophysiology and development of therapeutics. Nat. Rev. Drug. Discovery 2007, 6, 662â 680,  DOI: 10.1038/nrd2222
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      67
      Peroxynitrite: biochemistry, pathophysiology and development of therapeutics
      Szabo, Csaba; Ischiropoulos, Harry; Radi, Rafael
      Nature Reviews Drug Discovery (2007), 6 (8), 662-680CODEN: NRDDAG; ISSN:1474-1776. (Nature Publishing Group)
      A review. Peroxynitrite - the product of the diffusion-controlled reaction of nitric oxide with superoxide radical - is a short-lived oxidant species that is a potent inducer of cell death. Conditions in which the reaction products of peroxynitrite have been detected and in which pharmacol. inhibition of its formation or its decompn. have been shown to be of benefit include vascular diseases, ischemia-reperfusion injury, circulatory shock, inflammation, pain and neurodegeneration. In this review, the authors first discuss the biochem. and pathophysiol. of peroxynitrite and then focus on pharmacol. strategies to attenuate the toxic effects of peroxynitrite. These include its catalytic redn. to nitrite and its isomerization to nitrate by metalloporphyrins, which have led to potential candidates for drug development for cardiovascular, inflammatory and neurodegenerative diseases.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®

      68
      Apparent hydroxyl radical production by peroxynitrite: implications for endothelial injury from nitric oxide and superoxide
      Beckman, Joseph S.; Beckman, Tanya W.; Chen, Jun; Marshall, Patricia A.; Freeman, Bruce A.
      Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America (1990), 87 (4), 1620-4CODEN: PNASA6; ISSN:0027-8424.
      Peroxynitrite has a pKa of 7.49 at 37Â° and rapidly decomps. once protonated with a half-life of 1.9 s at pH 7.4. Peroxynitrite decompn. generates a strong oxidant with reactivity similar to hydroxyl radical, as assessed by the oxidn. of deoxyribose or DMSO. Product yields indicative of hydroxyl radical were 5.1 and 24.3%, resp., of added peroxynitrite. Product formation was not affected by the metal chelator diethyltriaminepentaacetic acid, suggesting that iron was not required to catalyze oxidn. In contrast, desferrioxamine was a potent, competitive inhibitor of peroxynitrite-initiated oxidn. because of a direct reaction between desferrioxamine and peroxynitrite rather than by iron chelation. Superoxide dismutase may protect vascular tissue stimulated to produce superoxide and NO under pathol. conditions by preventing the formation of peroxynitrite.

      71
      Substrate-induced redox change of selenium in glutathione peroxidase studied by x-ray photoelectron spectroscopy
      Wendel, A.; Pilz, W.; Ladenstein, R.; Sawatzki, G.; Weser, U.
      Biochimica et Biophysica Acta, Enzymology (1975), 377 (1), 211-15CODEN: BBEZAD; ISSN:0924-1086.
      Glutathione peroxidase showed an x-ray photoelectron spectroscopy signal of the Se 3d (3/2, 5/2) electrons at 54.4 eV. After the addn. of the acceptor substrate, H2O2, a marked shift of this signal to a value of 58.0 eV was obsd. Upon subsequent treatment with the donor substrate, glutathione, this chem. shift was reversed and the original signal was obtained. These data demonstrate that the enzyme-bound Se moiety participates in the catalytic process. From the chem. shift obtained, it is concluded that the enzyme shuttles between a selenol or selenol deriv. in its reduced form and a seleninyl or selenonyl compd. in its oxidized form.

      Kinetic study of the reaction of ebselen with peroxynitrite
      Masumoto, Hiroshi; Kissner, Reinhard; Koppenol, Willem H.; Sies, Helmut
      FEBS Letters (1996), 398 (2,3), 179-182CODEN: FEBLAL; ISSN:0014-5793. (Elsevier)
      The second-order rate const. for the reaction of ebselen with peroxynitrite (ONOO-) is (2.0Â±0.1)Ã106 M-1 s-1 at pHâ¥8 and 25Â°, 3-4 orders of magnitude higher than the rate consts. obsd. for cysteine, ascorbate, or methionine. The activation energy is relatively low, 12.8 kJ/mol. This is the fastest reaction of peroxynitrite obsd. so far. It may allow Se-contg. compds. to play a novel role in the defense against peroxynitrite, one of the important reactive species generated during inflammatory processes.

      A novel mitochondria-targeted two-photon fluorescent probe for dynamic and reversible detection of the redox cycles between peroxynitrite and glutathione
      Sun, Chunlong; Du, Wen; Wang, Peng; Wu, Yang; Wang, Baoqin; Wang, Jun; Xie, Wenjun
      Biochemical and Biophysical Research Communications (2017), 494 (3-4), 518-525CODEN: BBRCA9; ISSN:0006-291X. (Elsevier B.V.)
      Redox homeostasis is important for maintenance of normal physiol. functions within cells. Redox state of cells is primarily a consequence of precise balance between levels of reducing equiv. and reactive oxygen species. Redox homeostasis between peroxynitrite (ONOO-) and glutathione (GSH) is closely assocd. with physiol. and pathol. processes, such as prolonged relaxation in vascular tissues and smooth muscle prepns., attenuation of hepatic necrosis, and activation of matrix metalloproteinase-2. We report a two-photon fluorescent probe (TP-Se) based on water-sol. carbazole-based compd., which integrates with org. selenium, to monitor changes in ONOO-/GSH levels in cells. This probe can reversibly respond to ONOO- and GSH and exhibits high selectivity, sensitivity, and mitochondrial targeting. The probe was successfully applied to visualize changes in redox cycles during ONOO- outbreak and antioxidant GSH repair in cells. The probe will lead to significant development on redox events involved in cellular redox regulation.

      Winterbourn, C. C.; Hampton, M. B.; Livesey, J. H.; Kettle, A. J. Modeling the reactions of superoxide and myeloperoxidase in the neutrophil phagosome: implications for microbial killing. J. Biol. Chem. 2006, 281, 39860â 39869,  DOI: 10.1074/jbc.M605898200
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      74
      Modeling the Reactions of Superoxide and Myeloperoxidase in the Neutrophil Phagosome: Implications for Microbial Killing
      Winterbourn, Christine C.; Hampton, Mark B.; Livesey, John H.; Kettle, Anthony J.
      Journal of Biological Chemistry (2006), 281 (52), 39860-39869CODEN: JBCHA3; ISSN:0021-9258. (American Society for Biochemistry and Molecular Biology)
      Neutrophils kill bacteria by ingesting them into phagosomes where superoxide and cytoplasmic granule constituents, including myeloperoxidase, are released. Myeloperoxidase converts chloride and hydrogen peroxide to hypochlorous acid (HOCl), which is strongly microbicidal. However, the role of oxidants in killing and the species responsible are poorly understood and the subject of current debate. To assess what oxidative mechanisms are likely to operate in the narrow confines of the phagosome, the authors have used a kinetic model to examine the fate of superoxide and its interactions with myeloperoxidase. Known rate consts. for reactions of myeloperoxidase were used and substrate concns. estd. from neutrophil morphol. In the model, superoxide is generated at several mM/s. Most react with myeloperoxidase, which is present at millimolar concns., and rapidly convert the enzyme to compd. III. Compd. III turnover by superoxide is essential to maintain enzyme activity. Superoxide stabilizes at â¼25 Î¼M and hydrogen peroxide in the low micromolar range. HOCl prodn. is efficient if there is adequate chloride supply, but further knowledge on chloride concns. and transport mechanisms is needed to assess whether this is the case. Low myeloperoxidase concns. also limit HOCl prodn. by allowing more hydrogen peroxide to escape from the phagosome. In the absence of myeloperoxidase, superoxide increases to >100 Î¼M but hydrogen peroxide to only â¼30 Î¼M. Most of the HOCl reacts with released granule proteins before reaching the bacterium, and chloramine products may be effectors of its antimicrobial activity. Hydroxyl radicals should form only after all susceptible protein targets are consumed.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD28XhtlCrtrbL&md5=1525df6734b4a8719d6f7c7b592ac498
      open URL

      Yap, Y. W.; Whiteman, M.; Cheung, N. S. Chlorinative stress: an under appreciated mediator of neurodegeneration?. Cell Signal. 2007, 19, 219â 228,  DOI: 10.1016/j.cellsig.2006.06.013
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      75
      Chlorinative stress: an under appreciated mediator of neurodegeneration?
      Yap, Yann Wan; Whiteman, Matthew; Cheung, Nam Sang
      Cellular Signalling (2007), 19 (2), 219-228CODEN: CESIEY; ISSN:0898-6568. (Elsevier B.V.)
      A review. Oxidative stress has been implicated as playing a role in neurodegenerative disorders, such as ischemic stroke, Alzheimer's, Huntington's, and Parkinson's disease. Persuasive evidences have shown that microglial-mediated oxidative stress contributes significantly to cell loss and accompanying cognitive decline characteristic of the diseases. Based on the facts that (i) levels of catalytically active myeloperoxidase are elevated in diseased brains and (ii) myeloperoxidase polymorphism is assocd. with the risk of developing neurodegenerative disorders, HOCl as a major oxidant produced by activated phagocytes in the presence of myeloperoxidase is therefore suggested to be involved in neurodegeneration. Its assocn. with neurodegeneration is further showed by elevated level of 3-chlorotyrosine (bio-marker of HOCl in vivo) in affected brain regions as well as HOCl scavenging ability of neuroprotectants, desferrioxamine and uric acid. In this review, we will summary the current understanding concerning the assocn. of HOCl and neuronal cell death where prodn. of HOCl will lead to further formation of reactive nitrogen and oxygen species. In addn., HOCl also causes tissue destruction and cellular damage leading cell death.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®

      open URL

      Myeloperoxidase and chlorinated peptides in osteoarthritis: potential biomarkers of the disease
      Steinbeck, Marla J.; Nesti, Leon J.; Sharkey, Peter F.; Parvizi, Javad
      Journal of Orthopaedic Research (2007), 25 (9), 1128-1135CODEN: JOREDR; ISSN:0736-0266. (John Wiley & Sons, Inc.)
      Osteoarthritis (OA) is a disabling condition in which multiple initiating events or conditions (heritable and nonheritable) result in eventual loss of articular cartilage. However, the etiol. of OA remains poorly understood, and diagnosis of early disease is difficult due to the lack of specific identifiers. Recent literature suggests that a series of inflammatory processes may be involved in initiating and propagating OA. We hypothesized that products of neutrophils and macrophages, namely myeloperoxidase (MPO), a specific enzyme responsible for the prodn. of both highly reactive hypochlorous acid (HOCl) and chlorine gas (Cl2) and chlorinated peptides, may be present in the synovial fluid of patients with OA. We examd. the synovial fluid from 30 patients to identify and profile the presence of MPO. We divided the samples into three groups using radiog. and clin. assessment: (1) control, patients with acute knee injury with no history of OA and no radiog. evidence of OA; (2) early OA, patients with a mild OA based on radiographs; and (3) late OA, patients with a longstanding history of OA and with radiog. evidence of complete joint loss. Patients with early OA demonstrated significantly elevated levels of MPO. We also demonstrated the presence of HOCl and Cl2 modified proteins (Cl-peptides) in early OA synovial fluid samples by liq. chromatog. and mass spectrometry. Patients in the control and advanced OA groups demonstrated little elevation in MPO levels and Cl-peptides were undetectable. These results indicate that MPO and Cl-peptides may serve as diagnostic markers for the detection of early OA.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2sXhtVCqsLrF&md5=6140c5dffe60dfd2eba174978cb2fb37
      open URL
    77. 77
      Pattison, D. I.; Davies, M. J. Evidence for Rapid Inter- and Intramolecular Chlorine Transfer Reactions of Histamine and Carnosine Chloramines: Implications for the Prevention of Hypochlorous-Acid-Mediated Damage. Biochemistry 2006, 45, 8152â 8162,  DOI: 10.1021/bi060348s
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      77
      Evidence for Rapid Inter- and Intramolecular Chlorine Transfer Reactions of Histamine and Carnosine Chloramines: Implications for the Prevention of Hypochlorous-Acid-Mediated Damage
      Pattison, David I.; Davies, Michael J.
      Biochemistry (2006), 45 (26), 8152-8162CODEN: BICHAW; ISSN:0006-2960. (American Chemical Society)
      Hypochlorous acid (HOCl) is a powerful oxidant generated from H2O2 and Cl- by the heme enzyme myeloperoxidase, which is released from activated leukocytes. HOCl possesses potent antibacterial properties, but excessive prodn. can lead to host tissue damage that is implicated in a wide range of human diseases (e.g., atherosclerosis). Histamine and carnosine have been proposed as protective agents against such damage. However, as recent studies have shown that histidine-contg. compds. readily form imidazole chloramines that can rapidly chlorinate other targets, it was hypothesized that similar reactions may occur with histamine and carnosine, leading to propagation, rather than prevention, of HOCl-mediated damage. In this study, the reactions of HOCl with histamine, histidine, carnosine, and other compds. contg. imidazole and free amine sites were examd. In all cases, rapid formation (k, 1.6 Ã 105 M-1 s-1) of imidazole chloramines was obsd., followed by chlorine transfer to yield more stable, primary chloramines (R-NHCl). The rates of most of these secondary reactions are dependent upon substrate concns., consistent with intermol. mechanisms (k, 103-104 M-1 s-1). However, for carnosine, the imidazole chloramine transfer rates are independent of the concn., indicative of intramol. processes (k, 0.6 s-1). High-performance liq. chromatog. studies show that in all cases the resultant R-NHCl species can slowly chlorinate N-Î±-acetyl-Tyr. Thus, the current data indicate that the chloramines formed on the imidazole and free amine groups of these compds. can oxidize other target mols. but with limited efficiency, suggesting that histamine and particularly carnosine may be able to limit HOCl-mediated oxidn. in vivo.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD28Xlt1yqtrY%253D&md5=cb1de990baf7d54288910fb47ddba3b2
      open URL
    78. 78
      Pattison, I.; Davies, M. J. Absolute rate constants for the reaction of hypochlorous acid with protein side chains and peptide bonds. Chem. Res. Toxicol. 2001, 14, 1453â 1464,  DOI: 10.1021/tx0155451
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      78
      Absolute rate constants for the reaction of hypochlorous acid with protein side chains and peptide bonds
      Pattison, David I.; Davies, Michael J.
      Chemical Research in Toxicology (2001), 14 (10), 1453-1464CODEN: CRTOEC; ISSN:0893-228X. (American Chemical Society)
      Hypochlorous acid (HOCl) is a potent oxidant, which is produced in vivo by activated phagocytes. This compd. is an important antibacterial agent, but excessive or misplaced prodn. has been implicated in a no. of human diseases, including atherosclerosis, arthritis, and some cancers. Proteins are major targets for this oxidant, and such reaction results in side-chain modification, backbone fragmentation, and crosslinking. Despite a wealth of qual. data for such reactions, little abs. kinetic data is available to rationalize the in vitro and in vivo data. In this study, abs. second-order rate consts. for the reactions of HOCl with protein side chains, model compds., and backbone amide (peptide) bonds have been detd. at physiol. pH values. The reactivity of HOCl with potential reactive sites in proteins is summarized by the series: Met (3.8 Ã 107 M-1 s-1) > Cys (3.0 Ã 107 M-1 s-1) Â» cystine (1.6 Ã 105 M-1 s-1) â His (1.0 Ã 105 M-1 s-1) â Î±-amino (1.0 Ã 105 M-1 s-1) > Trp (1.1 Ã 104 M-1 s-1) > Lys (5.0 Ã 103 M-1 s-1) Â» Tyr (44 M-1 s-1) â Arg (26 M-1 s-1) > backbone amides (10-10-3 M-1 s-1) > Gln (0.03 M-1 s-1) â Asn (0.03 M-1 s-1). The rate consts. for reaction of HOCl with backbone amides (peptide bonds) vary by 4 orders of magnitude with uncharged peptide bonds reacting more readily with HOCl than those in a charged environment. These kinetic parameters have been used in computer modeling of the reactions of HOCl with human serum albumin, apolipoprotein-A1 and free amino acids in plasma at different molar excesses. These models are useful tools for predicting, and reconciling, exptl. data obtained in HOCl-induced oxidns. and allow estns. to be made as to the flux of HOCl to which proteins are exposed in vivo.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®

      open URL

      A BODIPY-based fluorescent probe, HCSe, has been successfully developed for the rapid detection of hypochlorous acid based on the specific HOCl-promoted oxidn. of di-Ph selenide in response to the amt. of HOCl. Confocal fluorescence microscopy imaging using RAW264.7 cells showed that the new probe HCSe could be used as an effective fluorescent probe for detecting HOCl in living cells.

      A simple and reversible fluorescent probe based on NBD for rapid detection of hypochlorite and its application for bioimaging
      Shen, Youming; Zhang, Xiangyang; Huang, Xi; Wen, Siyu; Liu, Mingdi; Deng, Yan; Zhang, Youyu; Zhang, Chunxiang; Jin, Junling; Li, Haitao; Yao, Shouzhuo
      RSC Advances (2015), 5 (97), 79519-79524CODEN: RSCACL; ISSN:2046-2069. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      A simple and reversible fluorescent probe bearing 7-nitrobenz-2-oxa-1,3-diazole and a selenomorpholine fragment was designed and synthesized. The probe showed highly selective, sensitive and fast (<10 s) recognition to hypochlorite in aq. solns. The relative results demonstrated that the linear response range of the probe was between 5.0 Ã 10-8 M and 1.2 Ã 10-4 M, with a low detection limit of 3.3 nM (S/N = 3). The probe was capable of monitoring hypochlorite reversibly in the presence of glutathione. In addn., the biol. applications in living cells have been described.

      Development of a selenide-based fluorescent probe for imaging hypochlorous acid in lysosomes
      Qu, Zongjin; Ding, Junxia; Zhao, Meiyu; Li, Peng
      Journal of Photochemistry and Photobiology, A: Chemistry (2015), 299 (), 1-8CODEN: JPPCEJ; ISSN:1010-6030. (Elsevier B.V.)
      The development of fluorescent probes for hypochlorous acid (HOCl) has received intense attention because of the biol. significance of HOCl. In this work, a novel fluorescent probe based on a selenide switch for the detection of HOCl in lysosomes has been designed and synthesized on a 1,8-naphthalimide scaffold. The probe exhibited a high selectivity for HOCl over various reactive oxygen species (ROS) with a fast response and a large fluorescence enhancement in aq. media. Confocal microscopy imaging of living cells indicated that the probe was able to accumulate in lysosomes and was successfully applied to imaging exogenous HOCl in living cells. Attempts of using Lyso-NI-Se to image HOCl in stimulated RAW264.7 cells failed, probably due to the absence of endogenous HOCl in lysosomes or the undesirable detection limit.

      Enhanced Fluorescence Turn-on Imaging of Hypochlorous Acid in Living Immune and Cancer Cells
      Mulay, Sandip V.; Choi, Minsuk; Jang, Yoon Jeong; Kim, Youngsam; Jon, Sangyong; Churchill, David G.
      Chemistry - A European Journal (2016), 22 (28), 9642-9648CODEN: CEUJED; ISSN:0947-6539. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      Two closely related Ph selenyl based boron-dipyrromethene (BODIPY) turn-on fluorescent probes for the detection of hypochlorous acid (HOCl) were synthesized for studies in chem. biol.; emission intensity is modulated by a photoinduced electron-transfer (PET) process. Probe 2 intrinsically shows a negligible background signal; however, after reaction with HOCl, chem. oxidn. of selenium forecloses the PET process, which evokes a significant increase in fluorescence intensity. The fluorescence intensity of probes 1 and 2 with HOCl involves an â¼18 and â¼50-fold enhancement compared with the resp. responses from other reactive oxygen/nitrogen species (ROS/RNS) and low detection limits (30.9 nM for 1 and 4.5 nM for 2). Both probes show a very fast response with HOCl; emission intensity reached a max. within 1 s. These probes show high selectivity for HOCl, as confirmed by confocal microscopy imaging when testing with RAW264.7 and MCF-7 cells.

      Substituent Effects in BODIPY in Live Cell Imaging
      Mulay, Sandip V.; Yudhistira, Tesla; Choi, Minsuk; Kim, Youngsam; Kim, Jinjoo; Jang, Yoon Jeong; Jon, Sangyong; Churchill, David G.
      Chemistry - An Asian Journal (2016), 11 (24), 3598-3605CODEN: CAAJBI; ISSN:1861-4728. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      Small-mol. organoselenium-based fluorescent probes possess great capacity in understanding biol. processes through the detection of various analytes such as reactive oxygen/nitrogen species (ROS/RNS), biothiols (cysteine, homocysteine and glutathione), lipid droplets, etc. Herein, we present how substituents on the BODIPY system play a significant part in the detection of biol. important analytes for in vitro conditions and live cell imaging studies. The fluorescence of the probe was quenched by 2-chloro and 6-Ph selenium groups; the probe shows high selectivity with NaOCl among other ROS/RNS, and gives a turn-on response. The max. fluorescence intensity is attained within â1-2 min with a low detection limit (19.6 nM), and shows a â110-fold fluorescence enhancement compared to signals generated for other ROS/RNS. Surprisingly, in live cell expts., the probe specifically located and accumulated in lipid droplets, and showed a fluorescence turn-on response. We believe this turn-on response occurred because of aggregation-induced emission (AIE), which surprisingly occurred only by introducing one lipophilic mesityl group at the meso position of the BODIPY.

      Overriding Phthalate Decomposition When Exploring Mycophenolic Acid Intermediates as Selenium-Based ROS Biological Probes
      Halle, Mahesh B.; Yudhistira, Tesla; Lee, Kyung Jin; Choi, Jae Hyuck; Kim, Youngsam; Park, Hee-Sung; Churchill, David G.
      ACS Omega (2018), 3 (10), 13474-13483CODEN: ACSODF; ISSN:2470-1343. (American Chemical Society)
      Hypochlorous (OCl-) acid is the most well-known bacterial oxidant to be produced by neutrophils. Excess amts. of OCl- can cause various disorders in living systems. Herein, the authors have designed, synthesized, and characterized two novel organoselenium-based target mols. (Probe-1 and Probe-OCl) based on a synthetic intermediate of mycophenolic acid (MPA) for the aq. detection of OCl-. Probe 1 has been recently reported (Org. Lett., 2018, 20, 3557-3561); both probes show immediate "turn on" fluorescence (< 1 s) upon the addn. of OCl-, display an increase in fluorescence quantum yield (3.7-fold in Probe-1 and 11.6-fold in Probe-OCl) and are completely sol. in aq. media without the help of any cosolvent. However, a decrease in "turn-on" intensity with the oxidized version of Probe-1 in cell assays due to the anhydride/phthalate functionality suggests probe degrdn. occurs based on hydrolytic action (probe degrdn. half-life of â¼1500 s at 15 Î¼M of Probe-1 and 150 Î¼M OCl). Thus, the change of "anhydride" to "methylamide" begets Probe-OCl which possesses more stability without sacrificing its water soly. properties and responses at short times. Further studies suggest that the Probe-OCl is highly stable within physiol. pH (pH = 7.4). Surprisingly, in live cell expts. involving U-2OS cells and HeLa cells, Probe-OCl accumulated and aggregated in lipid droplets (LDs) and gives a "turn-on" fluorescence response. MTT assays confirmed that Probe-OCl is not toxic. Cuvette aggregation studies were also performed (THF/H2O) to demonstrate aggregation-induced fluorescence at longer times. The current hypothesis is that the "turn-on" fluorescence effect is caused by the aggregation induced emission (AIE) mechanism available for Probe-OCl. In this case, in tandem the authors reanalyzed the Mes-BOD-SePh deriv. as well to compare and contrast cell localization as imaged by confocal microscopy; fluorescence emission occurs in the absence of, or prior to, Se oxidn.

      Gale, P. A. Anion and ion-pair receptor chemistry: highlights from 2000 and 2001. Coord. Chem. Rev. 2003, 240, 191â 221,  DOI: 10.1016/S0010-8545(02)00258-8
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      90
      Anion and ion-pair receptor chemistry: highlights from 2000 and 2001
      Gale, Philip A.
      Coordination Chemistry Reviews (2003), 240 (1-2), 191-221CODEN: CCHRAM; ISSN:0010-8545. (Elsevier Science B.V.)
      A review. This review article highlights advances made in abiotic anion coordination chem. in 2000 and 2001. The structure of this review is that similar to the previous reviews in this series that covered 1997, 1998 and 1999. The review also includes examples of ion-pair receptors. The 1st section examines anion receptors that do not contain metal ions. This is followed by a review of metal contg. anion receptors in which the metal can function as: (i) a coordination site for the anion; (ii) an agent withdrawing electron d. from the receptor; (iii) an organizational element in the receptor; (iv) a sensor; and (v) a co-bound guest in ion-pair receptor. Examples of the role of anions in directing the self-assembly of complex mol. architectures are presented in the final section.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®

      Martinez-Manez, R.; Sancenon, F. Fluorogenic and chromogenic chemosensors and reagents for anions. Chem. Rev. 2003, 103, 4419â 4476,  DOI: 10.1021/cr010421e
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      92
      Fluorogenic and Chromogenic Chemosensors and Reagents for Anions
      Martinez-Manez, Ramon; Sancenon, Felix
      Chemical Reviews (Washington, DC, United States) (2003), 103 (11), 4419-4476CODEN: CHREAY; ISSN:0009-2665. (American Chemical Society)
      A review. This review deals with the use of fluorogenic and chromogenic reagents for anions sensing. In this sense, it is remarkable that there are relatively few examples on anion sensing when compared with the literature devoted to anion recognition or when compared to cation sensing. However, the no. of papers on anion sensing has grown considerably. The present review is a comprehensive anal. about signaling of small anions using changes in fluorescence, luminescence, or color (no changes in fluorescence or color using anionic macromols. such as DNA are included) and will point out how the use of relatively simple mols. is leading to the development of new systems for the selective sensing of target anionic guests. These advances suggest that it would be possible soon to have selective reagents for screening a wide range of anions of environmental, biol., and medical importance. Anion signaling using fluorescence or color changes can also be obsd. using irreversible reactions. Here, the term chemosensor should not strictly be applied and terms such as reagents, reactants, or chemodosimeters should be used. Despite their irreversible nature, recent advances in the area of chemodosimeters for anions also were included in this review.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®

      Anion receptors based on organic frameworks: highlights from 2005 and 2006
      Gale, Philip A.; Garcia-Garrido, Sergio E.; Garric, Joachim

      A review. This crit. review covers advances in anion complexation chem. related to receptors based on org. frameworks in the years 2005-2006.       Sessler, J. L.; Seidel, D. Synthetic expanded porphyrin chemistry. Angew. Chem., Int. Ed. 2003, 42, 5134â 5175,  DOI: 10.1002/anie.200200561
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      94
      Synthetic expanded porphyrin chemistry
      Sessler, Jonathan L.; Seidel, Daniel
      Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2003), 42 (42), 5134-5175CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      A review. Expanded porphyrins are synthetic analogs of the porphyrins, and differ from these and other naturally occurring tetrapyrrolic macrocycles by contg. a larger central core with a min. of 17 atoms, while retaining the extended conjugation features that are a hallmark of these quintessential biol. pigments. The results of core expansion is to produce systems with novel spectral and electronic features, interesting and, often unprecedented, cation-coordination properties, and, in many cases, an ability to bind anions in certain protonation states. Also adding to the appeal of expanded porphyrins is their central role in addressing issues of aromaticity. In many cases, they also display structural features, such as decidedly nonpolar "figure-eight" motifs, that have no antecedents in the chem. of porphyrins or related macrocyclic compds. In this review, the various synthetic approaches now being employed to produce expanded porphyrins as well as their various applications-related aspects are discussed.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3sXptV2ntbg%253D&md5=13e418c897806e059ef81817b9814a8d
      open URL
    95. 95
      Gunnlaugsson, T.; Davis, A. P.; OâBrien, J. E.; Glynn, M. Synthesis and photophysical evaluation of charge neutral thiourea or urea based fluorescent PET sensors for bis-carboxylates and pyrophosphate. Org. Biomol. Chem. 2005, 3, 48â 56,  DOI: 10.1039/b409018g
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      95
      Synthesis and photophysical evaluation of charge neutral thiourea or urea based fluorescent PET sensors for bis-carboxylates and pyrophosphate
      Gunnlaugsson, Thorfinnur; Davis, Anthony P.; O'Brien, John E.; Glynn, Mark
      Organic & Biomolecular Chemistry (2005), 3 (1), 48-56CODEN: OBCRAK; ISSN:1477-0520. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      The synthesis of the fluorescent photoinduced electron transfer (PET) chemosensors 1-3 for bis-anions such as bis-carboxylates and pyrophosphate in org. solvents is described herein. These sensors are based on the receptor-spacer-fluorophore-spacer-receptor motif where the receptors are charge neutral arom. thiourea or urea receptors and the fluorophore is anthracene. The anion recognition was evaluated using 1H NMR as well as absorption and fluorescence spectroscopy in DMSO. For simple anions such as acetate or fluoride, the recognition is through hydrogen bonding of the corresponding anion to the receptors. This gave rise to only minor changes in the absorption spectra, but significant changes in the fluorescence emission spectra, which was substantially (70-95%) quenched. Anal. of these recognition events implied a 1:2 (sensor:anion) binding and ideal PET behavior for ions such as AcO- and H2PO4-. For F-, the luminescent quenching indicated a 1:1 binding, but this was due more to complete quenching of the excited state after the addn. of one equiv. of the anion. For all of the anions, the quenching contributed to enhanced efficiency of PET from the receptors to the excited state of the fluorophore. In the case of the bis-anions (ambient), such as di-carboxylates, similar fluorescence quenching was obsd. However, here either a 1:1 or a 1:2 binding was obsd. depending on the length of the spacer sepg. the two carboxylate moieties and the nature of the receptor. Whereas both pyrophosphate and malonate gave rise to a 1:1 binding, glutarate gave rise to â¼1:2 binding for the thiourea sensors 1 and 2. However, for the urea based sensor 3, the binding is 1:1 for all the bis-anions. For such a 1:1 binding probably the anion most likely bridges the fluorophore moiety. This was also evident from the 1H NMR (DMSO-d6) spectrum where the anthracene resonances were significantly affected. By simply modifying the electronic structure of the receptor, the sensitivity of the recognition process could also be modified; e.g. compd. 1, bearing the trifluoromethyl substituent, showed stronger binding to the bis-anions than 2, which possessed a simple Ph moiety.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2cXhtVylt7rK&md5=042e49e5190aca551cd76c11e1784ffc
      open URL

      Lin, Y.-S.; Tu, G.-M.; Lin, C.-Y.; Chang, Y.-T.; Yen, Y.-P. Colorimetric anion chemosensors based on anthraquinone: Naked-eye detection of isomeric dicarboxylate and tricarboxylate anions. New J. Chem. 2009, 33, 860â 867,  DOI: 10.1039/b811172c
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      96
      Colorimetric anion chemosensors based on anthraquinone: naked-eye detection of isomeric dicarboxylate and tricarboxylate anions
      Lin, Yi-Shan; Tu, Guan-Min; Lin, Chi-Yung; Chang, Yen-Tzu; Yen, Yao-Pin
      New Journal of Chemistry (2009), 33 (4), 860-867CODEN: NJCHE5; ISSN:1144-0546. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      Three new colorimetric anion receptors I (X=S, R=NO2; X=O, R=NO2; X=S, R=CF3) were synthesized and characterized. Among them, both I (X=S, R=NO2) and I (X=S, R=CF3) showed good sensitivity and selectivity for discrimination of maleate vs. fumarate or malate vs. tartrate by dramatic color changes in DMSO or DMSO-H2O (95:5). Thus, both I (X=S, R=NO2) and I (X=S, R=CF3) can be used as optical chemosensors for recognition of maleate vs. fumarate or malate vs. tartrate anion. Besides that, the receptor I (X=S, R=NO2) has also a unique color change for recognition of either cis-aconitate or trans-aconitate in DMSO, accordingly it can be used for detection of each isomer and discrimination of cis-aconitate from trans-aconitate anion.

      Recognition of carboxylate anions and carboxylic acids by selenium-based new chromogenic fluorescent sensor: A remarkable fluorescence enhancement of hindered carboxylates
      Goswami, Shyamaprosad; Hazra, Anita; Chakrabarty, Rinku; Fun, Hoong-Kun
      Organic Letters (2009), 11 (19), 4350-4353CODEN: ORLEF7; ISSN:1523-7060. (American Chemical Society)
      A selenium metal-based new fluorescence sensor 5-pivaloylamino-1,2,5-selenodiazolo[3,4-d]pyrimidin-7-(6H)-one (receptor 1) is reported for the recognition of monocarboxylic acids and carboxylate anions both by UV-visible and fluorescence methods. Receptor 1 recognizes carboxylate anions more than monocarboxylic acids and it is a selective sensor for carboxylates with specially hindered carboxylate anions. The changes of fluorescence intensity are remarkably enhanced with red shift in presence of bulky carboxylate anions. The x-ray crystal structure of receptor 1 with pivalic acid is reported.

      Rahman, I.; MacNee, W. Regulation of redox glutathione levels and gene transcription in lung inflammation: therapeutic approaches. Free Radical Biol. Med. 2000, 28, 1405â 1420,  DOI: 10.1016/S0891-5849(00)00215-X
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      99
      Regulation of redox glutathione levels and gene transcription in lung inflammation: therapeutic approaches
      Rahman, I.; MacNee, W.
      Free Radical Biology & Medicine (2000), 28 (9), 1405-1420CODEN: FRBMEH; ISSN:0891-5849. (Elsevier Science Inc.)
      A review with 178 refs. Glutathione (l-Î³-glutamyl-l-cysteinylglycine, GSH), is a vital intra- and extracellular protective antioxidant. Glutathione is synthesized from its constituent amino acids by the sequential action of Î³-glutamylcysteine synthetase (Î³-GCS) and GSH synthetase. The rate-limiting enzyme in GSH synthesis is Î³-GCS. Gamma-GCS expression is modulated by oxidants, phenolic antioxidants, and inflammatory and anti-inflammatory agents in various mammalian cells. The intracellular GSH redox homeostasis is strictly regulated to govern cell metab. and protect cells against oxidative stress. Growing evidence has suggested that cellular oxidative processes have a fundamental role in inflammation through the activation of stress kinases (JNK, MAPK, p38) and redox-sensitive transcription factors such as NF-ÎºB and AP-1, which differentially regulate the genes for pro-inflammatory mediators and protective antioxidant genes such as Î³-GCS, Mn-SOD, and heme oxygenase-1. The crit. balance between the induction of pro-inflammatory mediators and antioxidant genes and the regulation of the levels of GSH in response to oxidative stress at the site of inflammation is not known. Knowledge of the mechanisms of redox GSH regulation and gene transcription in inflammation could lead to the development of novel therapies based on the pharmacol. manipulation of the prodn. of this important antioxidant in inflammation and injury. This FORUM article features the role of GSH levels in the regulation of transcription factors, whose activation and DNA binding leads to pro-inflammatory and antioxidant gene transcription. The potential role of thiol antioxidants as a therapeutic approach in inflammatory lung diseases is also discussed.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®

      Glutathione-Mediated Delivery and Release Using Monolayer Protected Nanoparticle Carriers
      Hong, Rui; Han, Gang; Fernandez, Joseph M.; Kim, Byoung-jin; Forbes, Neil S.; Rotello, Vincent M.
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2006), 128 (4), 1078-1079CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      We demonstrate here the effective delivery of a dye payload into cells using 2-nm core gold nanoparticles, with release occurring via place exchange of glutathione onto the particle surface. In vitro expts. demonstrate effective release of drug analogs upon addn. of glutathione. Cell culture expts. show rapid uptake of nanoparticle and effective release of payload. The role of glutathione in the release process was demonstrated through improved payload release upon transient increase in glutathione levels achieved via introduction of glutathione Et ester into the cell.

    101. 101
      Kemp, M.; Go, Y. M.; Jones, D. P. Nonequilibrium thermodynamics of thiol/disulfide redox systems: A perspective on redox systems biology. Free Radical Biol. Med. 2008, 44, 921â 937,  DOI: 10.1016/j.freeradbiomed.2007.11.008
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      101
      Nonequilibrium thermodynamics of thiol/disulfide redox systems: A perspective on redox systems biology
      Kemp, Melissa; Go, Young-Mi; Jones, Dean P.
      Free Radical Biology & Medicine (2008), 44 (6), 921-937CODEN: FRBMEH; ISSN:0891-5849. (Elsevier)
      A review. Understanding the dynamics of redox elements in biol. systems remains a major challenge for redox signaling and oxidative stress research. Central redox elements include evolutionarily conserved subsets of cysteines and methionines of proteins which function as S switches and labile reactive O species (ROS) and reactive N species (RNS) which function in redox signaling. The S switches depend on redox environments in which rates of oxidn. are balanced with rates of redn. through the thioredoxins, glutathione/glutathione disulfide, and cysteine/cystine redox couples. These central couples, which we term redox control nodes, are maintained at stable but nonequil. steady states, are largely independently regulated in different subcellular compartments, and are quasi-independent from each other within compartments. Disruption of the redox control nodes can differentially affect S switches, thereby creating a diversity of oxidative stress responses. Systems biol. provides approaches to address the complexity of these responses. In the present review, we summarize thiol/disulfide pathway, redox potential, and rate information as a basis for kinetic modeling of S switches. The summary identifies gaps in knowledge esp. related to redox communication between compartments, definition of redox pathways, and discrimination between types of S switches. A formulation for kinetic modeling of GSH/GSSG redox control indicates that systems biol. could encourage novel therapeutic approaches to protect against oxidative stress by identifying specific redox-sensitive sites which could be targeted for intervention.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1cXjtVCitrs%253D&md5=4f643b237093a45ba07aea9b14650a0f
      open URL

      Seshadri, S.; Beiser, A.; Selhub, J.; Jacques, P. F.; Rosenberg, I. H.; DâAgostino, R. B.; Wilson, P. W. F.; Wolf, P. A. Plasma Homocysteine as a Risk Factor for Dementia and Alzheimerâs Disease. N. Engl. J. Med. 2002, 346, 476â 83,  DOI: 10.1056/NEJMoa011613
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      103
      Plasma homocysteine as a risk factor for dementia and Alzheimer's disease
      Seshadri, Sudha; Beiser, Alexa; Selhub, Jacob; Jacques, Paul F.; Rosenberg, Irwin H.; D'Agostino, Ralph B.; Wilson, Peter W. F.; Wolf, Philip A.
      New England Journal of Medicine (2002), 346 (7), 476-483CODEN: NEJMAG; ISSN:0028-4793. (Massachusetts Medical Society)
      Background In cross-sectional studies, elevated plasma homocysteine levels have been assocd. with poor cognition and dementia. Studies of newly diagnosed dementia are required in order to establish whether the elevated homocysteine levels precede the onset of dementia or result from dementia-related nutritional and vitamin deficiencies. Methods A total of 1092 subjects without dementia (667 women and 425 men; mean age, 76 yr) from the Framingham Study constituted our study sample. We examd. the relation of the plasma total homocysteine level measured at base line and that measured eight years earlier to the risk of newly diagnosed dementia on follow-up. We used multivariable proportional-hazards regression to adjust for age, sex, apolipoprotein E genotype, vascular risk factors other than homocysteine, and plasma levels of folate and vitamins B12 and B6. Results Over a median follow-up period of eight years, dementia developed in 111 subjects, including 83 given a diagnosis of Alzheimer's disease. The multivariable-adjusted relative risk of dementia was 1.4 (95 percent confidence interval, 1.1 to 1.9) for each increase of 1 SD in the log-transformed homocysteine value either at base line or eight years earlier. The relative risk of Alzheimer's disease was 1.8 (95 percent confidence interval, 1.3 to 2.5) per increase of 1 SD at base line and 1.6 (95 percent confidence interval, 1.2 to 2.1) per increase of 1 SD eight years before base line. With a plasma homocysteine level greater than 14 Î¼mol per L, the risk of Alzheimer's disease nearly doubled. Conclusions An increased plasma homocysteine level is a strong, independent risk factor for the development of dementia and Alzheimer's disease.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD38XhtFCktrw%253D&md5=0c2fe7caf78f95e6e9a06ec8774f7b7f
      open URL

      Savage, D. G.; Lindenbaum, J.; Stabler, S. P.; Allen, R. H. Sensitivity of serum methylmalonic acid and total homocysteine determinations for diagnosing cobalamin and folate deficiencies. Am. J. Med. 1994, 96, 239â 246,  DOI: 10.1016/0002-9343(94)90149-X
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      104
      Sensitivity of serum methylmalonic acid and total homocysteine determinations for diagnosing cobalamin and folate deficiencies
      Savage, David G.; Lindenbaum, John; Stabler, Sally P.; Allen, Robert H.
      American Journal of Medicine (1994), 96 (3), 239-46CODEN: AJMEAZ; ISSN:0002-9343. (Excerpta Medica)
      Patients with cobalamin (vitamin B12) deficiency usually lack many of the classic features of severe megaloblastic anemia; because of the low diagnostic specificity of decreased serum cobalamin levels, demonstrating the deficiency unequivocally is often difficult. We examd. the sensitivity of measuring serum concns. of methylmalonic acid and total homocysteine for diagnosing patients with clear-cut cobalamin deficiency and compared the results with those of patients with clear-cut folate deficiency. Serum metabolites were measured for all patients seen from 1982 to 1989 at two university hospitals who met the criteria for cobalamin and folate deficiency states and for such patients seen from 1968 to 1981 from whom stored sera were available. In all, 406 patients had 434 episodes of cobalamin deficiency and 119 patients had 123 episodes of folate deficiency. Criteria for deficiency states included serum vitamin levels, hematol. and neurol. findings, and responses to therapy. Responses were documented in 97% of cobalamin-deficient patients and 76% of folate-deficient patients. Metabolite levels were measured by modified techniques using capillary-gas chromatog. and mass spectrometry. Most of the cobalamin-deficient patients had underlying pernicious anemia; two thirds were blacks or Latinos. Hematocrits were normal in 28% and mean cell vols. in 17%. Of the 434 episodes of cobalamin deficiency, 98.4% of serum methylmalonic acid levels and 95.9% of serum homocysteine levels were elevated (greater than 3 std. deviations above the mean in normal subjects). Only one patient had normal levels of both metabolites. Serum homocysteine levels were increased in 91% of the 123 episodes of folate deficiency. Methylmalonic acid was elevated in 12.2% of the folate-deficient patients; in all but one, the elevation was attributable to renal insufficiency or hypovolemia. For the cobalamin-deficient patients, measuring serum metabolite concns. proved to be a highly sensitive test of deficiency. We conclude that normal levels of both methylmalonic acid and total homocysteine rule out clin. significant cobalamin deficiency with virtual certainty.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK2MXpsVWgsLc%253D&md5=f8eeb4caf20995583ce0082fe082add5
      open URL
    105. 105
      Hwang, C.; Sinskey, A. J.; Lodish, H. F. Oxidized redox state of glutathione in the endoplasmic reticulum. Science 1992, 257, 1496â 1502,  DOI: 10.1126/science.1523409
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      105
      Oxidized redox state of glutathione in the endoplasmic reticulum
      Hwang, Christopher; Sinskey, Anthony J.; Lodish, Harvey F.
      Science (Washington, DC, United States) (1992), 257 (5076), 1496-502CODEN: SCIEAS; ISSN:0036-8075.
      The redox state of the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) was measured with the peptide N-acetyl-Asn-Tyr-Thr-Cys-NH2. The peptide diffused across cellular membranes; some became glycosylated and thus trapped within the secretory pathway, and its cysteine residue underwent reversible thiol-disulfide exchanges with the surrounding redox buffer. Glycosylated peptides from cells were disulfide-linked to glutathione, indicating that glutathione is the major redox buffer in the secretory pathway. The redox state of the secretory pathway was more oxidative than that of the cytosol; the ratio of reduced glutathione to the disulfide form (GSH/GSSG) within the secretory pathway ranged 1:1-3:1, whereas the overall cellular GSH/GSSG ratio ranged 30:1-100:1. Cytosolic glutathione was also transported into the lumen of microsomes in a cell-free system. Although the way in which ER maintains an oxidative environment is not known, these results suggest that the demonstrated preferential transport of GSSG compared to GSH into the ER lumen may contribute to this redox compartmentation.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK38XmtlSksb8%253D&md5=a7e183757ede28b8637862f4a9bbf1d4
      open URL
    106. 106
      Dalle-Donne, I.; Rossi, R.; Colombo, G.; Giustarini, D.; Milzani, A. Protein S-glutathionylation: a regulatory device from bacteria to humans. Trends Biochem. Sci. 2009, 34, 85â 96,  DOI: 10.1016/j.tibs.2008.11.002
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      106
      Protein S-glutathionylation: a regulatory device from bacteria to humans
      Dalle-Donne, Isabella; Rossi, Ranieri; Colombo, Graziano; Giustarini, Daniela; Milzani, Aldo
      Trends in Biochemical Sciences (2009), 34 (2), 85-96CODEN: TBSCDB; ISSN:0968-0004. (Elsevier B.V.)
      A review. S-Glutathionylation is the specific post-translational modification of protein cysteine residues by the addn. of the tripeptide glutathione, the most abundant and important low-mol.-mass thiol within most cell types. Protein S-glutathionylation is promoted by oxidative or nitrosative stress but also occurs in unstressed cells. It can serve to regulate a variety of cellular processes by modulating protein function and to prevent irreversible oxidn. of protein thiols. Recent findings support an essential role for S-glutathionylation in the control of cell-signaling pathways assocd. with viral infections and with tumor necrosis factor-induced apoptosis. Glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate dehydrogenase has recently been implicated in the regulation of endothelin-1 synthesis by a novel S-glutathionylation-based mechanism involving mRNA stability. Moreover, recent studies have identified S-glutathionylation as a redox signaling mechanism in plants.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXitVOkurg%253D&md5=63f2131a84157b3521d590e58e733d37
      open URL

      A Rhodamine-Based Fluorescent Probe Containing a Se-N Bond for Detecting Thiols and Its Application in Living Cells

      Here the authors report a new rhodamine-based fluorescent probe (I) contg. a selenium-nitrogen bond for detecting thiols based on the nucleophilic substitution of sulfhydryl. The probe was successfully applied to the imaging of thiols in both HL-7702 cells and HepG2 cells with high sensitivity and selectivity.

    108. 108
      Wang, R.; Chen, L.; Liu, P.; Zhang, Q.; Wang, Y. Sensitive near-infrared fluorescent probes for thiols based on Se-N bond cleavage: imaging in living cells and tissues. Chem.âEur. J. 2012, 18, 11343â 11349,  DOI: 10.1002/chem.201200671
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      108
      Sensitive Near-Infrared Fluorescent Probes for Thiols Based on S-N Bond Cleavage: Imaging in Living Cells and Tissues
      Wang, Rui; Chen, Lingxin; Liu, Ping; Zhang, Qin; Wang, Yunqing
      Chemistry - A European Journal (2012), 18 (36), 11343-11349, S11343/1-S11343/5CODEN: CEUJED; ISSN:0947-6539. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      Cy-NiSe and Cy-TfSe were designed and synthesized as sensitive near-IR (NIR) fluorescent probes for detecting thiols on the basis of Se-N bond cleavage both in cells and in tissues. Since a donor-excited photoinduced electron transfer (d-PET) process occurs between the modulator and the fluorophore, Cy-NiSe and Cy-TfSe have weak fluorescence. On titrn. with glutathione, the free dye exhibits significant fluorescence enhancement. The two probes are sensitive and selective for thiols over other relevant biol. species. They can function rapidly at pH 7.4, and their emission lies in the NIR region. Confocal imaging confirms that Cy-NiSe and Cy-TfSe can be used for detecting thiols in living cells and tissues.

      Evans, R. M.; Fraser, J. B.; Owen, L. N. 61. Dithiols. Part III. Derivatives of polyhydric alcohols. J. Chem. Soc. 1949, 248,  DOI: 10.1039/jr9490000248

      Dithiols. III. Derivatives of polyhydric alcohols
      Evans, R. M.; Fraser, J. B.; Owen, L. N.
      Journal of the Chemical Society (1949), (), 248-55CODEN: JCSOA9; ISSN:0368-1769.
      CH2:CHCH.CH2.O (I) (10 g.), added slowly to a cooled mixt. of 50 g. Ac2O and 5 g. concd. HCl and the mixt. heated 16 h. on the steam bath, gives 17 g. CH2:CHCH(OAc)CH2OAc (II), b12 94-8Â°, nD23 1.4330; 10 g. I and 50 g. Ac2O contg. 0.1 g. ZnCl2, heated 16 h. on the steam bath, give 9.2 g. II. I (50 g.) in 200 cc. CHCl3, treated dropwise at about 10Â° (10 h.) with 115 g. Br in 250 cc. CHCl3, gives 53 g. BrCH2CHBrCH.CH2.O (III), b10 98-9Â°, nD20 1.5435. II (100 g.) in 500 cc. CHCl3, treated (4 h.) at 10Â° with 95 g. Br in 200 cc. CHCl3, gives 160 g. 1,2-dibromo-3,4-diacetoxybutane (IV), b0.1 95Â°, nD21 1.4990; a less pure product results from III, Ac2O, and concd. HCl (12 h. on the steam bath). IV (160 g.) and 125 g. AcSK in 700 cc. EtOH, refluxed 6 h., give 31.5 g. 1,2-diacetoxy-3,4-bis(acetylmercapto)butane (V), m. 78Â°, absorption max. at 2310 A., Îµ 7300; the mother liquor at -20Â° gives 11.5 g. of an isomer (VI), m. 68Â°, absorption max. at 2290 A., Îµ 7900. V (19.5 g.) in 100 cc. N EtOH-HCl, kept 4 h. at 60Â° in a N atm., gives 2.4 g. 1,2-dimercapto-1,3-butanediol (VA), b0.05 118-20Â°, nD18 1.5820 (diisopropylidene deriv., m. 63Â°), and 2.5 g. of the anhydro compd., b0.05 76-9Â°, nD18 1.5800 (bisphenylurethane, m. 142Â°). VI gives a mixt. of the dithiol and anhydro compd. (diisopropylidene deriv., m. 82Â°). CHâ¡CCH:CHCH2OH (65 g.), hydroxylated with H2O2 and HCO2H and treated with Ac2O and AcONa, gives 54 g. 3,4,5-triacetoxy-1-pentyne, b0.8 120Â°, m. 51Â°, nD18 1.4525; semihydrogenation gives a nearly quant. yield of 3,4,5-triacetoxy-1-pentene (VII), b12 143Â°, nD12 1.4420. Br (37.5 g.) in 100 cc. CCl4, gradually added to 52 g. VII in 500 cc. CCl4 at 10Â°, gives 87 g. 1,2-dibromo-3,4,5-triacetoxypentane, b0.001 125-30Â°, yielding on standing 35 g. solid (VIII), m. 84Â°; 65 g. VIII and 50 g. AcSK in EtOH, refluxed 6 h., give 48% 3,4,5-triacetoxy-1,2-bis(acetylmercapto)pentane (IX), b0.001 125-30Â°, a small portion of which m. 92Â°; the liq. isomer gives the same results; hydrolysis of IX with N (MeO)2Ba in MeOH gives the dithiol (IXA), analyzed as the Ba deriv. DL-[BrCH2CH(OAc)]2 (X) (40 g.) and 30 g. AcSK in boiling EtOH give 24 g. DL-1,4-dithiothreitol tetraacetate [DL-threo-1,4-dimercapto-3,4-butanediol tetraacetate] (XI), m. 73Â°, absorption max. at 2290 A., Îµ 7700. XI (21 g.) in 100 cc. N MeOH-HCl, refluxed 4 h., gives 9.2 g. 1,4-dithiothreitol (XIA), b2 125-30Â°, m. 42-3Â° (diisopropylidene deriv., m. 78Â°). The meso isomer of X (10 g.) and 10 g. AcSK in 75 cc. EtOH, refluxed 2 h., give 7.5 g. 1,4-dithioerythritol tetraacetate [erythro-isomer of XI], m. 126Â°, absorption max. at 2290 A., Îµ 7600. 1,4-Dithioerythritol, m. 82-3Â° (diisopropylidene deriv., m. 145Â°). Mannitol hexaacetate (150 g.) in 25% HBr in 700 cc. AcOH, heated 9 h. at 35Â°, gives 25 g. of the 1,6-dibromide (XII), m. 200Â°. Sorbitol hexaacetate (6 h. at 37Â°) gives 2,3,4,5-tetraacetylsorbitol 1,6-dibromohydrin, m. 196Â°. XII (24 g.) and 15 g. AcSK in 150 cc. EtOH, refluxed 7 h., give 22 g. hexaacetyl-1,6-dithiomannitol, m. 188Â°, which is hydrolyzed to 1,6-dithiomannitol (XIIA), m. 172Â°. DL-(AcOCH2CHBr)2 (145 g.) and 112 g. AcSK in 500 cc. EtOH, refluxed 4 h., give 52 g. (AcOCH2CH:)2; it results also from the reactants in C5H5N (48 h. at room temp.) or with 7% MeOH-NaSH (5 days at 18-20Â°). The isomeric dichlorobutanediol diacetates react with AcSK much more slowly than the Br analogs; considerable decompn. occurs and little or none of the corresponding acetylated dithiols are obtained. The present work shows that, although it is often possible to prep. the fully acetylated poly-HO dithiols in a pure state, their deacetylation, except in the case of the nonvicinal dithiols, frequently proceeds abnormally. HSCH2CH(SH)CH2OH (XIII) (50 g.), 250 g. Ac2O, and 60 g. AcONa give 98 g. of the triacetate (XIV), b0.1 139Â°, nD20 1.5140, absorption max. at 2300 A., Îµ 7900. XIV (20 g.) in 100 cc. N MeOH-HCl, refluxed 3 h., gives 43% XIII and a quantity of high-boiling residue; 20% aq. NaOH at 20Â° (48 h.) gives only 35% XIII; it is known that XIII yields HSCH2CH.CH2.S on distn. in vacuo, which accounts for the low yield in the hydrolysis of XIV. XIII (20 g.) with 40 g. Me2SO4 in 20% aq. NaOH at 75-95Â° gives 18 g. of the dithio-Me ether, b9 127-30Â°, nD19 1.5488 (1-naphthylurethane, m. 71Â°). The Î±- and Î²-glyceryl ethers of XIII, Î³-mercaptovalerothiolactone, VA, and IXA are approx. equal (on a mol. basis) to XIII in activity against mapharside poisoning in mice; the 1st 4 compds. are approx. as toxic as XIII but IXA is substantially less so. The acetates of the first 2 and last 2 compds. have very low toxicities, but are therapeutically ineffective. XIA is more toxic than XIII and it greatly accelerates death when administered after mapharside; XIIA has a toxic action not shown by any of the other dithiols and produces a wasting disease, accompanied by paralysis.

      Cleland, W. W. Dithiothreitol, a New Protective Reagent for SH Group. Biochemistry 1964, 3, 480â 482,  DOI: 10.1021/bi00892a002

      112
      Dithiothreitol, a new protective reagent for SH groups
      Cleland, W. W.
      Biochemistry (1964), 3 (4), 480-2CODEN: BICHAW; ISSN:0006-2960.
      Because of its low oxidn.-redn. potential (-0.33 v. at pH 7), dithiothreitol (and its isomer, dithioerythritol) is capable of maintaining monothiols completely in the reduced state and of reducing disulfides quant. Since this compd. is a highly water-soluble solid with little odor and little tendency to be oxidized directly by air, it should prove much superior to the thiols now used as protective reagents for SH groups.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaF2cXmvFCqsw%253D%253D&md5=3d97cdc9aaf329681ac68f0b55533469

    113. 113
      Alliegro, M. C. Effects of dithiothreitol on protein activity unrelated to thiolâdisulfide exchange: for consideration in the analysis of protein function with clelandâs reagent. Anal. Biochem. 2000, 282, 102â 106,  DOI: 10.1006/abio.2000.4557
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      113
      Effects of Dithiothreitol on Protein Activity Unrelated to Thiol-Disulfide Exchange: For Consideration in the Analysis of Protein Function with Cleland's Reagent
      Alliegro, Mark C.
      Analytical Biochemistry (2000), 282 (1), 102-106CODEN: ANBCA2; ISSN:0003-2697. (Academic Press)
      Dithiothreitol (DTT) is widely used to reduce disulfide bonds in the anal. of protein structure and function. However, thiol-disulfide exchange is not the only mechanism whereby DTT can alter protein function. We observe that DTT diminishes the carbohydrate binding activity of a cysteine-less mutant of pigpen as well as it inhibits the intact mol. Lack of inhibition by threitol, a deriv. of the four-carbon sugar threose, indicates that the thiol groups of DTT are required for inhibition, and also that DTT is not acting as a simple carbohydrate competitor. Moreover, inhibition of pigpen-carbohydrate binding is not likely due to metal chelation because pigpen binding to carbohydrate is insensitive to EDTA and 1,10-phenanthroline, which would otherwise be expected to mimic the DTT effect. Our results suggest that DTT can interact with protein domains in the absence of cysteine residues, and that the biochem. reactivity of DTT is not necessarily one and the same with its assumed biochem. specificity. (c) 2000 Academic Press.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3cXktVGrs7o%253D&md5=547d18cfa4c7240dd766a437ae8c170f
      open URL

      Ates, B.; Ercal, B. C.; Manda, K.; Abraham, L.; Ercal, N. Determination of glutathione disulfide levels in biological samples using thiolâdisulfide exchanging agent, dithiothreitol. Biomed. Chromatogr. 2009, 23, 119â 123,  DOI: 10.1002/bmc.1083
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      114
      Determination of glutathione disulfide levels in biological samples using thiol-disulfide exchanging agent, dithiothreitol
      Ates, Burhan; Ercal, Baris Can; Manda, Kalyan; Abraham, Linu; Ercal, Nuran
      Biomedical Chromatography (2009), 23 (2), 119-123CODEN: BICHE2; ISSN:0269-3879. (John Wiley & Sons Ltd.)
      A reversed-phase HPLC method incorporating dithiothreitol (DTT) redn. for quant. detn. of oxidized glutathione (GSSG) in biol. samples is described here. This method is based on a previous enzymic redn. technique that uses N-1-(pyrenyl) maleimide (NPM) as a derivatizing agent. In the earlier method, glutathione disulfide (GSSG) was measured by first reducing it to GSH with glutathione reductase (GR) in the presence of NADPH. However, this is a very costly and time-consuming technique. The method described here employs a common and inexpensive thiol-disulfide exchanging agent, DTT, for the redn. of GSSG to GSH, followed by derivatization with NPM. The calibration curves are linear over a concn. range of 25-1250 nM (r2 > 0.995). The coeffs. of variations for intra-run precision and inter-run precision range from 0.49 to 5.10% with an accuracy range of 1.78-6.15%. The percentage of relative recovery ranges from 97.3 to 103.2%. This new method provides a simple, efficient, and cost-effective way of detg. glutathione disulfide levels with a 2.5 nM limit of detection per 5 Î¼L injection vol.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®

      Spear, N.; Aust, S. D. The Effects of Different Buffers on the Oxidation of DNA by Thiols and Ferric Iron. J. Biochem. Mol. Toxicol. 1998, 12, 125â 132,  DOI: 10.1002/(SICI)1099-0461(1998)12:2<125::AID-JBT7>3.0.CO;2-N
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      115
      The effects of different buffers on the oxidation of DNA by thiols and ferric iron
      Spear, Nathan; Aust, Steven D.
      Journal of Biochemical and Molecular Toxicology (1998), 12 (2), 125-132CODEN: JBMTFQ; ISSN:1095-6670. (John Wiley & Sons, Inc.)
      Because buffers can act as metal ligands, they can effect several reactions necessary for DNA oxidn. by ferric iron and thiols, such as iron redn. Therefore, these reactions were studied in Hepes and phosphate buffers and unbuffered NaCl. Redn. of Fe3+ by dithiothreitol (DTT) and cysteine was obsd. in either Hepes or NaCl solns., but not in phosphate buffer. Thiyl radicals were obsd. in Hepes, but there was much less thiyl radical prodn. in the saline or phosphate solns. Redox cycling between either DTT or cysteine and Fe3+ also resulted in dioxygen consumption in Hepes buffer. Redn. of Fe3+ and O2 resulted in the formation of an oxidant capable of producing 8-hydroxy-2'-deoxyguanosine (8-OHdG) in calf thymus DNA. The highest levels of 8-OHdG were detected when DTT or cysteine and Fe3+ were incubated in Hepes, while much less DNA oxidn. was detected when the expt. was done in a saline soln., and almost no DNA oxidn. occurred in the phosphate buffer. These results demonstrate that the use of different buffers can greatly affect the ability of thiols to promote iron-dependent oxidns.

      Taatjes, D. J.; Gaudiano, G.; Koch, T. H. Production of formaldehyde and dna-adriamycin or dna-daunomycin adducts, initiated through redox chemistry of dithiothreitol/iron, xanthine oxidase/nadh/iron, or glutathione/iron. Chem. Res. Toxicol. 1997, 10, 953â 961,  DOI: 10.1021/tx970064w
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      116
      Production of Formaldehyde and DNA-Adriamycin or DNA-Daunomycin Adducts, Initiated through Redox Chemistry of Dithiothreitol/Iron, Xanthine Oxidase/NADH/Iron, or Glutathione/Iron
      Taatjes, Dylan J.; Gaudiano, Giorgio; Koch, Tad H.
      Chemical Research in Toxicology (1997), 10 (9), 953-961CODEN: CRTOEC; ISSN:0893-228X. (American Chemical Society)
      The reaction of the antitumor drugs adriamycin and daunomycin with the self-complementary DNA oligonucleotide (GC)4 to generate DNA-drug adducts was investigated as a function of redox reaction conditions. The redox systems dithiothreitol (DTT)/Fe(III) and xanthine oxidase/NADH both gave the same distribution of four DNA-anthracycline adducts. In each of these adducts the anthracycline is bonded via a methylene linkage between the 3'-amino group of the drug and the 2-amino group of a deoxyguanosine of the DNA. The methylene linkage results from reaction of the drug and DNA with in situ-generated formaldehyde via Schiff base chem. [Taatjes, D. J., Gaudiano, G., Resing, K., and Koch, T. H. (1997) J. Med. Chem. 39, 1276-1286]. Formaldehyde prodn. is promoted by iron, inhibited by metal-chelating agents, and does not require drug. Iron enhances formaldehyde prodn. by a factor of 30, EDTA inhibits its formation by a factor of 2, and Desferal inhibits its formation by a factor of more than 20. Hydrogen peroxide accumulates in significant quantities only with xanthine oxidase/NADH in the presence of Desferal. The results are explained in terms of Fenton oxidn. of Tris buffer to formaldehyde. Biol. reagents also cause DNA-drug adduct formation; redn. of ferric ion with glutathione in phosphate buffer in the presence of spermine produced the same DNA-drug adducts. The observations are discussed in terms of cytotoxicity resulting from iron chelated to adriamycin catalyzing in vivo prodn. of formaldehyde which links adriamycin to DNA and tumor cell resistance resulting from factors which decrease formaldehyde.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK2sXmtVehsr0%253D&md5=3be6b5801d4d88b1505014e89ea68296

    117. 117
      Gurr, J. R.; Bau, D. T.; Liu, F.; Lynn, S.; Jan, K. Y. Dithiothreitol enhances arsenic trioxide-induced apoptosis in NB4 cells. Mol. Pharmacol. 1999, 56, 102â 109,  DOI: 10.1124/mol.56.1.102
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      117
      Dithiothreitol enhances arsenic trioxide-induced apoptosis in NB4 cells
      Gurr, Jia-Ran; Bau, Da-Tian; Liu, Fount; Lynn, Shugene; Jan, Kun-Yan
      Molecular Pharmacology (1999), 56 (1), 102-109CODEN: MOPMA3; ISSN:0026-895X. (American Society for Pharmacology and Experimental Therapeutics)
      Recently, arsenic trioxide (As2O3) was reported to induce clin. remission in patients with acute promyelocytic leukemia. Modulation of protein phosphorylation by binding to the vicinal thiols has been suggested as a possible mechanism. We found that phenylarsine oxide, a strong vicinal thiol-binding agent, neither induced nuclear fragmentation or DNA laddering nor increased caspase activity in NB4 cells; however, As2O3 and a weak thiol-binding agent, dimethylarsinic acid, did increase activity. Dithiothreitol (DTT) effectively suppressed the phenylarsine oxide-inhibited cellular reductive capacity, but unexpectedly, enhanced As2O3-induced apoptosis in NB4 cells. As2O3-induced and As2O3-plus-DTT-induced apoptosis in NB4 cells was modulated by oxidant modifiers, but not by nitric oxide synthase inhibitors. These results demonstrate that DTT, a dithiol agent and known antidote for trivalent inorg. arsenic, enhances the toxicity of As2O3, thereby opening a new research direction for the mechanisms of arsenic toxicity and perhaps also helping in the development of new therapeutic strategies for treating leukemias.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK1MXksFOmt7w%253D&md5=01e0f14fac4476dfdec14d840b4c4238
      open URL

      Hultberg, B.; Andersson, A.; Isaksson, A. Interaction of metals and thiols in cell damage and glutathione distribution: potentiation of mercury toxicity by dithiothreitol. Toxicology 2001, 156, 93â 100,  DOI: 10.1016/S0300-483X(00)00331-0
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      118
      Interaction of metals and thiols in cell damage and glutathione distribution: potentiation of mercury toxicity by dithiothreitol
      Hultberg, B.; Andersson, A.; Isaksson, A.
      Toxicology (2001), 156 (2-3), 93-100CODEN: TXCYAC; ISSN:0300-483X. (Elsevier Science Ireland Ltd.)
      In the present study, the authors have investigated the effects of extracellular redox status and metal/thiol interactions on glutathione distribution in HeLa cell cultures. No effects were seen on glutathione distribution after the addn. of different thiols whereas the pro-oxidant copper ions affected glutathione distribution in several ways. The addn. of dithiothreitol (DTT) but not the other thiols potentiated the effects of mercury ions on glutathione distribution and cell toxicity. In the presence of DTT, increased intra- and extracellular glutathione concns. were noted already at 0.05 Î¼mol/L, which was below the previously reported toxicity threshold for mercury ions in blood. Likewise, DTT potentiated the effects of copper ions on glutathione distribution and cell toxicity whereas the addn. of DTT to cell cultures with a non-metal thiol reactive agent (hydroquinone) or an oxidative agent (hydrogen peroxide) did not affect glutathione distribution or cell toxicity. Thus, it seems as the synergistic effects between DTT and thiol reactive agents only apply to metal ions.

      A highly selective ratiometric fluorescent probe for 1,4-dithiothreitol (DTT) detection
      Zhu, Baocun; Zhang, Xiaoling; Jia, Hongying; Li, Yamin; Liu, Haipeng; Tan, Weihong
      Organic & Biomolecular Chemistry (2010), 8 (7), 1650-1654CODEN: OBCRAK; ISSN:1477-0520. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      A highly selective ratiometric fluorescent probe, which contains an aminonaphthalimide fluorophore and a self-immolative spacer for 1,4-dithiothreitol (DTT) detection was designed and synthesized. The probe displays a 66 nm red shift of fluorescence emission and the color changes from colorless to jade-green upon reaction with DTT. These properties are mechanistically ascribed to the strong reducing capability of DTT.
