        Fluorescent Probes Containing Selenium as a Guest or Host
        Wu, Di; Chen, Liyan; Kwon, Nahyun; Yoon, Juyoung
        Chem (2016), 1 (5), 674-698CODEN: CHEMVE; ISSN:2451-9294. (Cell Press)
        Selenium is an important trace element in living systems. Proteins incorporating selenium have a wide range of biol. effects, ranging from anti-oxidant and anti-inflammatory effects to the prodn. of active thyroid hormones. In the past decades, selenium has drawn enormous attention because of its important role in biol., which can be ascribed partly if not solely to its redox and hard and soft donor properties. With the use of chem. mimicry, a large no. of selenium-related fluorescent probes have been developed for monitoring physiol. and pathol. processes. This review, which summarizes recent progress made in this area, comprises two major sections. In the first section, fluorescent probes for selenium-contg. species, such as selenocysteine (Sec), hydrogen selenide, thioredoxin reductases (TrxRs), and selenite, are described. This is followed by a discussion of fluorescent probes that contain selenium and detect reactive oxygen, nitrogen, and sulfur species, as well as cations and anions.

        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar

        Photoactivity and optical applications of organic materials containing selenium and tellurium
        Hoover, Gabrielle C.; Seferos, Dwight S.
        Chemical Science (2019), 10 (40), 9182-9188CODEN: CSHCCN; ISSN:2041-6520. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        A review. Sulfur-contg. compds., particularly derivs. of thiophene, are well studied for org. optoelectronic applications. Incorporating selenium or tellurium in place of sulfur imparts different phys. properties due to the fundamental differences of these atoms relative to their lighter analogs. This has a profound influence on the properties of mols. and materials that incorporate chalcogens that may ultimately lead to new opportunities and applications. This mini-review will focus on the quant. and qual. photophys. characteristics of org. materials contg. selenium and tellurium as well as their emerging applications as mol. photoactive species, including light-emitting sensors, triplet sensitizers, and beyond.

        Ebselen-Agents for Sensing, Imaging and Labeling: Facile and Full-Featured Application in Biochemical Analysis
        Zhang, Jiawei; Yang, Lei; Wang, Yuxin; Cao, Tianyi; Sun, Zhiwei; Xu, Jie; Liu, Yuxia; Chen, Guang
        ACS Applied Bio Materials (2021), 4 (3), 2217-2230CODEN: AABMCB; ISSN:2576-6422. (American Chemical Society)
        A review. Phenyl-1,2-benzoselenazol-3(2H)-one (ebselen) is a classical mimic of glutathione peroxidase (GPx). Thioredoxin interaction endows ebselen attractive biol. functions, such as antioxidn. and anti-infection, as well as versatile therapeutic usage. Accordingly, application of ebselen analogs in biosensing, chem. labeling, imaging anal., disease pathol., drug development, clin. treatment, etc. have been widely developed, in which mercaptans, reactive oxygen species, reactive sulfur species, peptides, and proteins were involved. Herein, focusing on the application of ebselen-agents in biochem., we have made a systematic summary and comprehensive review. First, we summarized both the classical and the innovative methods for prepg. ebselen-agents to present the synthetic strategies. Then we discussed the full functional applicability of ebselen analogs in three fields of biochem. anal. including the fluorescence sensing and bioimaging, derivatization for high throughput fluorescence anal., and the labeling gents for proteomics. Finally, we discussed the current challenges and perspectives for ebselen-agents as anal. tools in biol. research. By presenting the multifunctional applicability of ebselen, we hope this review could appeal researchers to design the ebselen-related biomaterials for biochem. anal.

        Liu, Y.; Yu, Y.; Zhao, Q.; Tang, C.; Zhang, H.; Qin, Y.; Feng, X.; Zhang, J. Fluorescent probes based on nucleophilic aromatic substitution reactions for reactive sulfur and selenium species: Recent progress, applications, and design strategies. Coord. Chem. Rev. 2021, 427, 213601,  DOI: 10.1016/j.ccr.2020.213601
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        32
        Fluorescent probes based on nucleophilic aromatic substitution reactions for reactive sulfur and selenium species: Recent progress, applications, and design strategies
        Liu, Yuning; Yu, Yanan; Zhao, Qingyu; Tang, Chaohua; Zhang, Huiyan; Qin, Yuchang; Feng, Xiaohui; Zhang, Junmin
        Coordination Chemistry Reviews (2021), 427 (), 213601CODEN: CCHRAM; ISSN:0010-8545. (Elsevier B.V.)
        A review. Reactive sulfur species (RSS) and reactive selenium species (RSeS) are important substances for the maintenance of physiol. balance. Imbalance of RSS and RSeS is closely related to a series of human diseases, so it is considered to be an important biomarker in early diagnosis, treatment, and stage monitoring. Fast and accurate quant. anal. of different RSS and RSeS in complex biol. systems may promote the development of personalized diagnosis and treatment in the future. One way to explore the physiol. function of various types of RSS and RSeS in vivo is to detect them at the mol. level, and one of the most effective methods for this is to use fluorescent probes. Nucleophilic arom. substitution (SNAr) reactions are commonly exploited as a detection mechanism for RSS and RSeS in fluorescent probes. In this review, we cover recent progress in fluorescent probes for RSS and RSeS based on SNAr reactions, and discuss their response mechanisms, properties, and applications. Benzenesulfonate, phenyl-O ether, phenyl-S ether, phenyl-Se ether, 7-nitro-2,1,3-benzoxadiazole (NBD), benzoate, and selenium-nitrogen bonds are all good detection groups. Moreover, based on an integration of different reports, we propose the design and synthesis of RSS- and RSeS-selective probes based on SNAr reactions, current challenges, and future research directions, considering the selection of active sites, the effect of substituents on the benzene ring, and the introduction of other functional groups.

        Discussions of fluorescence in selenium chemistry: recently reported probes, particles, and a clearer biological knowledge
        Abdillah, Ariq; Sonawane, Prasad M.; Kim, Donghyeon; Mametov, Dooronbek; Shimodaira, Shingo; Park, Yunseon; Churchill, David G.
        Molecules (2021), 26 (3), 692CODEN: MOLEFW; ISSN:1420-3049. (MDPI AG)
        A review. In this review from literature appearing over about the past 5 years, we focus on selected selenide reports and related chem.; we aimed for a digestible, relevant, review intended to be usefully interconnected within the realm of fluorescence and selenium chem. Tellurium is mentioned where relevant. Topics include selenium in physics and surfaces, nanoscience, sensing and fluorescence, quantum dots and nanoparticles, Au and oxide nanoparticles quantum dot based, coatings and catalyst poisons, thin film, and aspects of solar energy conversion. Chemosensing is covered, whether small mol. or nanoparticle based, relating to metal ion analytes, H2S, as well as analyte sulfane (biothiols-including glutathione). We cover recent reports of probing and fluorescence when they deal with redox biol. aspects. Selenium in therapeutics, medicinal chem. and skeleton cores is covered. Selenium serves as a constituent for some small mol. sensors and probes. Typically, the selenium is part of the reactive, or active site of the probe; in other cases, it is featured as the analyte, either as a reduced or oxidized form of selenium. Free radicals and ROS are also mentioned; aggregation strategies are treated in some places. Also, the relationship between reduced selenium and oxidized selenium is developed.

        Pirillo, J.; De Simone, B. C.; Russo, N. Photophysical properties prediction of selenium- and tellurium-substituted thymidine as potential UVA chemotherapeutic agent. Theor. Chem. Acc. 2016, 135 (1), 1â 5,  DOI: 10.1007/s00214-015-1744-1

        Photophysical properties prediction of selenium- and tellurium-substituted thymidine as potential UVA chemotherapeutic agents
        Pirillo, Jenny; De Simone, Bruna Clara; Russo, Nino
        Theoretical Chemistry Accounts (2016), 135 (1), 1-5CODEN: TCACFW; ISSN:1432-2234. (Springer)
        D. functional theory and time-dependent d. functional theory calcn. for a series of photophys. properties (absorption spectra, singlet and triplet excitation energies and spin-orbit matrix elements) have been performed on the sulfur-, selenium- and tellurium-substituted thymine. The heavy atoms have been substituted in 2 or 4 and in both 2,4 position of the thymine ring. Different pathways for the population of the lowest triplet state have been considered. We find that all the considered systems are potential UVA chemotherapeutic agents since the lowest triplet states lie above the energy required for the prodn. of the highly cytotoxic 1 Îg excited oxygen mol. and due to the possible and efficient intersystem crossings ensured by high spin-orbit coupling values.

        Wolfe, M. F.; Schwarzbach, S.; Sulaiman, R. A. Effects of mercury on wildlife: A comprehensive review. Environ. Toxicol. Chem. 1998, 17, 146â 160,  DOI: 10.1002/etc.5620170203
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        35
        Effects of mercury on wildlife: a comprehensive review
        Wolfe, Marti F.; Schwarzbach, Steven; Sulaiman, Rini A.
        Environmental Toxicology and Chemistry (1998), 17 (2), 146-160CODEN: ETOCDK; ISSN:0730-7268. (SETAC Press)
        A review with 147 refs. Wildlife may be exposed to mercury (Hg) and methylmercury (MeHg) from a variety of environmental sources, including mine tailings, industrial effluent, agricultural drainwater, impoundments, and atm. deposition from elec. power generation. Terrestrial and aquatic wildlife may be at risk from exposure to waterborne Hg and MeHg. The transformation of inorg. Hg by anaerobic sediment microorganisms in the water column produces MeHg, which bioaccumulates at successive trophic levels in the food chain. If high trophic level feeders, such as piscivorous birds and mammals, ingest sufficient MeHg in prey and drinking water, Hg toxicoses, including damage to nervous, excretory and reproductive systems, result. Currently accepted no obsd. adverse effect levels (NOAELs) for waterborne Hg in wildlife have been developed from the piscivorous model in which most dietary Hg is in the Me form. Such model are not applicable to omnivores, insectivores, and other potentially affected groups, and have not incorporated data from other important matrixes, such as eggs and muscle. The purpose of this paper is to present a comprehensive review of the Hg literature as it relates to effects on wildlife, including previously understudied groups. The authors present a critique of the current state of knowledge about effects of Hg on wildlife as an aid to identifying missing information and to planning research needed for conducting a complete assessment of Hg risks to wildlife. This review summarizes the toxicity of Hg to birds and mammals, the mechanisms of Hg toxicity, the measurement of Hg in biota, and interpretation of residue data.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK1cXmsFamtw%253D%253D&md5=9fe4a8fbf9cc3607046bcb1161e6a713
        open URL
      36. 36
        Boening, D. W. Ecological effects, transport, and fate of mercury: a general review. Chemosphere 2000, 40, 1335â 1351,  DOI: 10.1016/S0045-6535(99)00283-0
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        36
        Ecological effects, transport, and fate of mercury: a general review
        Boening, Dean W.
        Chemosphere (2000), 40 (12), 1335-1351CODEN: CMSHAF; ISSN:0045-6535. (Elsevier Science Ltd.)
        A review and discussion with many refs. Mercury at low concns. represents a major hazard to microorganisms. Inorg. mercury has been reported to produce harmful effects at 5 Î¼g/l in a culture medium. Organomercury compds. can exert the same effect at concns. 10 times lower than this. The org. forms of mercury are generally more toxic to aquatic organisms and birds than the inorg. forms. Aquatic plants are affected by mercury in water at concns. of 1 mg/l for inorg. mercury and at much lower concns. of org. mercury. Aquatic invertebrates widely vary in their susceptibility to mercury. In general, organisms in the larval stage are most sensitive. Me mercury in fish is caused by bacterial methylation of inorg. mercury, either in the environment or in bacteria assocd. with fish gills or gut. In aquatic matrixes, mercury toxicity is affected by temp., salinity, dissolved oxygen and water hardness. A wide variety of physiol., reproductive and biochem. abnormalities have been reported in fish exposed to sublethal concns. of mercury. Birds fed inorg. mercury show a redn. in food intake and consequent poor growth. Other (more subtle) effects in avian receptors have been reported (i.e., increased enzyme prodn., decreased cardiovascular function, blood parameter changes, immune response, kidney function and structure, and behavioral changes). The form of retained mercury in birds is more variable and depends on species, target organ and geog. site. With few exceptions, terrestrial plants (woody plants in particular) are generally insensitive to the harmful effects of mercury compds.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3cXit1yru7k%253D&md5=a72dade319d43e17db03d04d132cb3d9
        open URL

        A review on the clin. toxicol. features of mercury vapor, Me and Et mercury, and inorg. divalent mercury. At present, exposure of the general population to mercury comes from three major sources, namely, fish consumption, dental amalgams, and vaccines. Each has its own characteristic form of mercury and distinctive toxicol. profile and clin. symptoms.

        Carvalho, C. M. L.; Chew, E.-H.; Hashemy, S. S.; Lu, J.; Holmgren, A. Inhibition of the Human Thioredoxin System. J. Biol. Chem. 2008, 283, 11913â 11923,  DOI: 10.1074/jbc.M710133200
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        38
        Inhibition of the Human Thioredoxin System: A MOLECULAR MECHANISM OF MERCURY TOXICITY
        Carvalho, Cristina M. L.; Chew, Eng-Hui; Hashemy, Seyed Isaac; Lu, Jun; Holmgren, Arne
        Journal of Biological Chemistry (2008), 283 (18), 11913-11923CODEN: JBCHA3; ISSN:0021-9258. (American Society for Biochemistry and Molecular Biology)
        Mercury toxicity mediated by different forms of mercury is a major health problem; however, the mol. mechanisms underlying toxicity remain elusive. The authors analyzed the effects of mercuric chloride (HgCl2) and monomethylmercury (MeHg) on the proteins of the mammalian thioredoxin system, thioredoxin reductase (TrxR) and thioredoxin (Trx), and of the glutaredoxin system, glutathione reductase (GR) and glutaredoxin (Grx). HgCl2 and MeHg inhibited recombinant rat TrxR with IC50 values of 7.2 and 19.7 nM, resp. Fully reduced human Trx1 bound mercury and lost all five free thiols and activity after incubation with HgCl2 or MeHg, but only HgCl2 generated dimers. Mass spectra anal. demonstrated binding of 2.5 mol of Hg2+ and 5 mol of MeHg+/mol of Trx1 with the very strong Hg2+ complexes involving active site and structural disulfides. Inhibition of both TrxR and Trx activity was obsd. in HeLa and HEK 293 cells treated with HgCl2 or MeHg. GR was inhibited by HgCl2 and MeHg in vitro, but no decrease in GR activity was detected in cell exts. treated with mercurials. Human Grx1 showed similar reactivity as Trx1 with both mercurial compds., with the loss of all free thiols and Grx dimerization in the presence of HgCl2, but no inhibition of Grx activity was obsd. in lysates of HeLa cells exposed to mercury. Overall, mercury inhibition was selective toward the thioredoxin system. In particular, the remarkable potency of the mercury compds. to bind to the selenol-thiol in the active site of TrxR should be a major mol. mechanism of mercury toxicity.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1cXltVyku7k%253D&md5=2cb08bc620dd999446b782751e2dc76b
        open URL

        Nolan, E. M.; Lippard, S. J. Tools and Tactics for the optical detection of Mercuric Ion. Chem. Rev. 2008, 108, 3443â 3480,  DOI: 10.1021/cr068000q
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar

        Tools and Tactics for the Optical Detection of Mercuric Ion
        Nolan, Elizabeth M.; Lippard, Stephen J.
        Chemical Reviews (Washington, DC, United States) (2008), 108 (9), 3443-3480CODEN: CHREAY; ISSN:0009-2665. (American Chemical Society)
        A review. The purpose of the present review is to provide a comprehensive account of recent progress in the design and application of optical sensors for mercury. A significant body of literature, guided by seminal work on cation sensing, describes the prepn. of small mol. Hg(II) detectors, and the authors highlight these strategies. The authors also cover complementary approaches that incorporate similar design principles and provide optical feedback, including Hg(II)-responsive biomols. and materials.

      40. 40
        Gutknecht, J. Inorganic mercury (Hg2+) transport through lipid bilayer membranes. J. Membr. Biol. 1981, 61, 61â 66,  DOI: 10.1007/BF01870753
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        40
        Inorganic mercury (Hg2+) transport through lipid bilayer membranes
        Gutknecht, John
        Journal of Membrane Biology (1981), 61 (1), 61-6CODEN: JMBBBO; ISSN:0022-2631.
        Diffusion of Hg2+ through planar lipid bilayer membranes was studied as a function of Cl- concn. and pH. Membranes were made from egg lecithin plus cholesterol in tetradecane. Tracer 203Hg flux and conductance measurements were used to est. the permeabilities to ionic and nonionic forms of Hg. At pH 7.0 and Cl- ranging from 10-1000 mM, only HgCl2 crosses the membrane at a significant rate. However, several other Hg complexes (HgOHCl, HgCl3-, and HgCl42-) contribute to diffusion through the aq. unstirred layer adjacent to the membrane. The relation between the total mercury flux (JHg), Hg concns., and permeabilities is: 1/JHg = 1/Pul[Hgt] + 1/Pm[HgCl2], where [Hgt] is the total concn. of all forms of Hg, Pul is the unstirred layer permeability, and Pm is the membrane permeability to HgCl2. By fitting this equation to the data, Pm = 1.3 Ã 10-2 cm/s. At Cl- concns. ranging from 1-100 mM, diffusion of Hgt through the unstirred layer is rate limiting. At Cl- concns. of 500-1000 mM, the membrane permeability to HgCl2 becomes rate limiting because HgCl2 comprises only â¼1% of the total Hg. Under all conditions, chem. reactions among Hg2+, Cl-, and(or) OH- near the membrane surface play an important role in the transport process. Other important metals, e.g., Zn2+, Cd2+, Ag+, and CH3Hg+, form neutral chloride complexes under physiol. conditions. Thus, it is likely that chloride can facilitate the diffusion of a variety of metals through lipid bilayer and biol. membranes.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaL3MXls1Cjsrc%253D&md5=b6f352b5f1bd3f9f5896faa14fe07bdb
        open URL
      41. 41
        Melnick, J. G.; Yurkerwich, K.; Parkin, G. On the chalcogenophilicity of Mercury: Evidence for a strong Hg-Se bond in [TmBut]HgSePh and its relevance to the toxicity of Mercury. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2010, 132, 647â 655,  DOI: 10.1021/ja907523x
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        41
        On the Chalcogenophilicity of Mercury: Evidence for a Strong Hg-Se Bond in [TmBut]HgSePh and Its Relevance to the Toxicity of Mercury
        Melnick, Jonathan G.; Yurkerwich, Kevin; Parkin, Gerard
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2010), 132 (2), 647-655CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        One of the reasons for the toxic effects of mercury has been attributed to its influence on the biochem. roles of selenium. For this reason, it is important to understand details pertaining to the nature of Hg-Se interactions and this has been achieved by comparison of a series of mercury chalcogenolate complexes that are supported by tris(2-mercapto-1-t-butyl-imidazolyl)hydroborato ligation, namely [TmBut]HgEPh (E = S, Se, Te). In particular, x-ray diffraction studies on [TmBut]HgEPh demonstrate that although the Hg-S bonds involving the [TmBut] ligand are longer than the corresponding Cd-S bonds of [TmBut]CdEPh, the Hg-EPh bonds are actually shorter than the corresponding Cd-EPh bonds, an observation which indicates that the apparent covalent radii of the metals in these compds. are dependent on the nature of the bonds. Furthermore, the difference in Hg-EPh and Cd-EPh bond lengths is a function of the chalcogen and increases in the sequence S (0.010 Ã) < Se (0.035 Ã) < Te (0.057 Ã). This trend indicates that the chalcogenophilicity of mercury increases in the sequence S < Se < Te. Thus, while mercury is often described as being thiophilic, it is evident that it actually has a greater selenophilicity, a notion that is supported by the observation of facile selenolate transfer from zinc to mercury upon treatment of [TmBut]HgSCH2C(O)N(H)Ph with [TmBut]ZnSePh. The significant selenophilicity of mercury is in accord with the aforementioned proposal that one reason for the toxicity of mercury is assocd. with it reducing the bioavailability of selenium.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXhsFOrtrjM&md5=e24d16e60149d6829e5a970a795729c6
        open URL

        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        42
        Interaction of mercuric ions with the bacterial growth medium and its effects on enzymic reduction of mercury
        Chang, Jo Shu; Hong, Juan; Ogunseitan, Oladele A.; Olson, Betty H.
        Biotechnology Progress (1993), 9 (5), 526-32CODEN: BIPRET; ISSN:8756-7938.
        The interaction of Hg2+ with components of Luria-Bertani broth (LB), used to grow the Hg-resistant strain Pseudomonas aeruginosa PU21 (Rip64), was studied using cold vapor at. absorption spectrometry and liq. scintillation counting. The time course anal. of free Hg2+ and total Hg in LB solns. showed that 30-40% of Hg2+ formed complexes with tryptone and yeast ext. within 140 h. Media contg. free or complexed Hg2+ were treated with cell-free mercuric reductase as well as with growing cells to investigate the effect of the Hg2+-LB interaction on Hg redn. In both assays, the complexed Hg2+ could not be reduced by mercuric reductase or P. aeruginosa PU21 (Rip64).

        43
        Mercuric ion inhibits the activity and fidelity of the human cell DNA synthesome
        Sekowski, Jennifer W.; Malkas, Linda H.; Wei, Yuetong; Hickey, Robert J.
        Toxicology and Applied Pharmacology (1997), 145 (2), 268-276CODEN: TXAPA9; ISSN:0041-008X. (Academic)
        We report here, for the first time, the use of an intact human cell multiprotein complex (which we have termed the DNA synthesome) to carry out full-length DNA replication and DNA synthesis in the presence of Hg2+ ion in vitro. In this study we report that DNA replication and DNA polymerase activity, as well as DNA replication fidelity of the human cell DNA synthesome, are specifically inhibited by physiol. attainable concns. of mercuric ion.

      44. 44
        Baum, C. R. Treatment of mercury intoxication. Curr. Opin. Pediatr 1999, 11, 265â 268,  DOI: 10.1097/00008480-199906000-00018
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        44
        Treatment of mercury intoxication
        Baum C R
        Current opinion in pediatrics (1999), 11 (3), 265-8 ISSN:1040-8703.
        The element mercury exists as inorganic, elemental, or organic species. Routes of exposure and toxicity in humans vary according to the species of mercury involved. Treatment of mercury poisoning generally requires the use of sulfhydryl bond-containing chelation agents, including the parenterally administered dimercaprol and its oral congeners. These oral chelators, meso-2,3-dimercaptosuccinic acid and sodium 2,3-dimercapto-1-propanesulfonate, have numerous advantages over dimercaprol, including less toxicity. Although dimercaprol is contraindicated in organic mercury exposures, meso-2,3-dimercaptosuccinic acid and sodium 2,3-dimercapto-1-propanesulfonate may be used to chelate all species of mercury. Recent evidence suggests that their efficacy in organic mercury poisoning is uncertain.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A280%3ADyaK1M3nvVOhtw%253D%253D&md5=f2cf31545dbeaa62cee9fe38a074a177
        open URL

        Tang, B.; Ding, B.; Xu, K.; Tong, L. Use of Selenium to detect mercury in water and cells: An enhancement of the sensitivity and specificity of a seleno fluorescent probe. Chem.âEur. J. 2009, 15, 3147â 3151,  DOI: 10.1002/chem.200802165
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        45
        Use of selenium to detect mercury in water and cells: an enhancement of the sensitivity and specificity of a seleno fluorescent probe
        Tang, Bo; Ding, Baiyu; Xu, Kehua; Tong, Lili
        Chemistry - A European Journal (2009), 15 (13), 3147-3151CODEN: CEUJED; ISSN:0947-6539. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        Inspired by the antitoxic function of Se towards heavy-metal ions, the authors designed an organoselenium fluorescent probe (FSe-1) for Hg. The reaction of FSe-1 and Hg2+ is an irreversible deselenation mechanism based on the selenophilic character of Hg. FSe-1 exhibits an ultrahigh selectivity and sensitivity for Hg2+ detection only for reactive Se atom sites due to the strong affinity between Se and Hg. FSe-1 was selective for Hg2+ ions over other relevant metal ions and bioanalytes, and also showed an enhancement in sensitivity of up to 1.0 nM, which is lower than the current Environmental Protection Agency std. for drinking H2O. Also, the new probe was successfully applied to the imaging of Hg ions in RAW 264.7 cells (a mouse macrophage cell line) with high sensitivity and selectivity.

        Fluorescent Phosphane Selenide as Efficient Mercury Chemodosimeter
        Samb, Issa; Bell, Jeremy; Toullec, Patrick Y.; Michelet, Veronique; Leray, Isabelle
        Organic Letters (2011), 13 (5), 1182-1185CODEN: ORLEF7; ISSN:1523-7052. (American Chemical Society)
        The synthesis and photophys. properties of a novel fluorescent sensor are described. The phosphorus-selenium moiety allowed a selective mercury salt complexation, followed by the formation of phosphane oxide, which leads to a turn-on of the fluorescence. The sensibility and selectivity toward mercury cations were evaluated (0.18 ppb) and are in complete agreement with the targeted level of the World Health Organization, which makes the dye an efficient dosimeter for mercury cations.

        47
        Facile synthesis of a monosulfonated triphenylphosphane (TPPMS) derived ligand having strong Ï-acceptor character
        Gulyas, Henrik; Bacsik, Zoltan; Szollosy, Aron; Bakos, Jozsef
        Advanced Synthesis & Catalysis (2006), 348 (10+11), 1306-1310CODEN: ASCAF7; ISSN:1615-4150. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        Two Ph rings of PPh3 were modified by electron-withdrawing trifluoromethyl groups. A methoxy group was introduced at the para-position of the 3rd ring. Due to the activating effect of the methoxy group, the phosphine [(4-methoxyphenyl)bis[4-(trifluoromethyl)phenyl]phosphine], which was complexed with Rh, can be monosulfonated under mild conditions and with complete selectivity. The novel ligand, Na 5-[bis(4-trifluoromethylphenyl)phosphino]-2-methoxybenzenesulfonate, was obtained in quant. yield, and it has an out-standing Ï-acceptor capacity among the known sulfonated triarylphosphines. It is not sol. in H2O but sol. in light alcs. and ionic liqs. Its soly. properties allow facile catalyst sepn. without H2O. The Na salt with [Rh(NBD)2]BF4 hydrogenated 76% of cinnamic aldehyde with complete selectivity for 3-phenylpropanal, whereas the yields using sodium 3-(diphenylphosphino)benzenesulfonate or sodium 5-(diphenylphosphino)-2-methoxybenzenesulfonate were much less.

        Shi, W.; Sun, S.; Li, X.; Ma, H. Imaging Different Interactions of Mercury and Silver with Live Cells by a Designed Fluorescence Probe Rhodamine B Selenolactone. Inorg. Chem. 2010, 49, 1206â 1210,  DOI: 10.1021/ic902192a
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        48
        Imaging Different Interactions of Mercury and Silver with Live Cells by a Designed Fluorescence Probe Rhodamine B Selenolactone
        Shi, Wen; Sun, Shuna; Li, Xiaohua; Ma, Huimin
        Inorganic Chemistry (2010), 49 (3), 1206-1210CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
        Rhodamine B selenolactone has been designed, synthesized, and characterized as a new fluorescent probe for imaging both Hg2+ and Ag+ in live cells to better understand their distinct toxicities to organisms. The probe is designed based on the fact that selenium has a strong affinity for mercury and silver, and is constructed by incorporating a Se atom into the spirocyclic structure of rhodamine. It exhibits a rapid and specific spectroscopic off-on response to Hg2+ and Ag+ instead of other species, with detection limits of 23 nM Hg2+ and 52 nM Ag+. Moreover, the probe is membrane-permeable, and can react with Ag+ even in the presence of Cl- because of the higher affinity of Se than Cl- for Ag+, which makes it of potential use for imaging not only Hg2+ but also Ag+ in live cells. This applicability has been demonstrated by imaging Hg2+ and Ag+ in Hela cells. It is obsd. that the reaction of Ag+ with the probe inside the cells occurs much slower than that of Hg2+, which is ascribed to the high concn. of cellular chloride ions inhibiting the formation of sufficient free Ag+. The present finding is helpful to get an insight into the different interaction mechanism of Hg2+ and Ag+ with cells, and more applications of the probe may be expected for studying the behaviors of Hg2+ and Ag+ in various biosystems.

        open URL

        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        51
        Solubility of silver sulfadiaine in physiological media and relevance to treatment of thermal burns with silver sulfadiazine cream
        Tsipouras, Nicholas; Rix, Colin J.; Brady, Peter H.
        Clinical Chemistry (Washington, D. C.) (1995), 41 (1), 87-91CODEN: CLCHAU; ISSN:0009-9147. (American Association for Clinical Chemistry)
        Silver sulfadiazine cream has been a std. treatment for burns over the past two decades. Although many studies have described the phenomenon of silver absorption from burn wounds treated with silver sulfadiazine, they failed to examine the chem. underlying the absorption process. Silver chloride was assumed to form at the burn wound and absorption of silver was believed to be negligible. Thus, chem. model systems were developed to investigate the interactions of silver sulfadiazine and silver chloride in direct contact with synthetic serum electrolyte soln. (SSES), with SSES plus endogenous ligands or beef blood plasma, and with human serum. The results indicate that silver absorption from an acute burn site can be significant, because human serum is capable of solubilizing silver. This finding is of concern, given the potential for silver toxicity as a direct consequence of applying silver sulfadiazine to extensive burn wounds.

        Dharmaraja, A. T. Role of reactive oxygen species (ROS) in therapeutics and drug resistance in cancer and bacteria. J. Med. Chem. 2017, 60, 3221â 3240,  DOI: 10.1021/acs.jmedchem.6b01243
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        55
        Role of Reactive Oxygen Species (ROS) in Therapeutics and Drug Resistance in Cancer and Bacteria
        Dharmaraja, Allimuthu T.
        Journal of Medicinal Chemistry (2017), 60 (8), 3221-3240CODEN: JMCMAR; ISSN:0022-2623. (American Chemical Society)
        A review. Evading persistent drug resistance in cancer and bacteria to most of the com. used drugs is necessary to restore the human health settings. A distinct property of cancer phenotype is enhanced glucose metab. and oxidative stress from normal cells. Reactive oxygen species (ROS) are metabolic byproducts of aerobic respiration and are responsible for maintaining redox homeostasis in cells. Maintaining the redox balance in cancerous cells are found to be crit. for their survival, which is modulated by reduced thiols and reducing cofactors NAD(P)H. Thus altering the levels reducing equiv. were found to enhance intracellular ROS and sensitize cancer cells to therapeutics. Similarly, Escherichia coli and life threatening infectious pathogens such as Staphylococcus aureus and Mycobacterium tuberculosis were found to be more sensitive to modulation of intracellular oxidative environment. Combination drug strategies were successfully employed in attenuating the effects of drug resistant cancer and bacterial. Here, a collection of some ROS modulation based cancer and bacterial therapeutics is presented.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2sXhvVSjsrY%253D&md5=71bfb8f37ab75364fedcb07de262fc2c
        open URL

        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar

        Bioreductively Activated Reactive Oxygen Species (ROS) Generators as MRSA Inhibitors
        Khodade, Vinayak S.; Sharath Chandra, Mallojjala; Banerjee, Ankita; Lahiri, Surobhi; Pulipeta, Mallikarjuna; Rangarajan, Radha; Chakrapani, Harinath
        ACS Medicinal Chemistry Letters (2014), 5 (7), 777-781CODEN: AMCLCT; ISSN:1948-5875. (American Chemical Society)
        The no. of cases of drug resistant Staphylococcus aureus infections is on the rise globally and new strategies to identify drug candidates with novel mechanisms of action are in urgent need. Here, we report the synthesis and evaluation of a series of benzo[b]phenanthridine-5,7,12(6H)-triones, which were designed based on redox-active natural products. We find that the in vitro inhibitory activity of 6-(prop-2-ynyl)benzo[b]phenanthridine-5,7,12(6H)-trione (I) against methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA), including a panel of patient-derived strains, is comparable or better than vancomycin. We show that the lead compd. generates reactive oxygen species (ROS) in the cell, contributing to its antibacterial activity.

        Wang, Y.; Gao, M.; Chen, Q.; Yu, F.; Jiang, G.; Chen, L. Associated detection of superoxide anion and Mercury(II) under chronic Mercury exposure in cells and mice models via a three-channel fluorescent probe. Anal. Chem. 2018, 90, 9769â 9778,  DOI: 10.1021/acs.analchem.8b01442
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        57
        Associated detection of superoxide anion and mercury(II) under chronic mercury exposure in cells and mice models via a three-channel fluorescent probe
        Wang, Yue; Gao, Min; Chen, Qingguo; Yu, Fabiao; Jiang, Guibin; Chen, Lingxin
        Analytical Chemistry (Washington, DC, United States) (2018), 90 (16), 9769-9778CODEN: ANCHAM; ISSN:0003-2700. (American Chemical Society)
        As a cytotoxic heavy metal ion, mercury(II) ion (Hg2+) induces severe oxidative stress and further results in physiol. dysfunction. Although mercury poisoning can be treated with many drugs, such as sodium selenite, the therapeutic effect is relatively poor, and it seems that the damage to human health continues. However, the interpretation for the pathogenesis has not been clarified yet. We supposed that the reason is attributed to Hg2+-caused intracellular oxidative stress. To confirm our hypothesis, we strived to design a three-channel ratio fluorescent probe, HCy-SeH, for superoxide anion (O2â¢-) and Hg2+ combined detection. O2â¢- is a vital precursor for other reactive oxygen species (ROS), which is involved in many physiol. and pathol. processes. However, until now there is no efficient chem. tool for O2â¢- and Hg2+ combined detection in cells and in vivo. The fluorescence response of our probe is initiated by a hydrogen abstraction reaction from the hydrocyanine fluorophore moiety. Once oxidized by O2â¢-, HCy-SeH recovers its Ï-conjugated system back to a heptamethine cyanine deriv., Cy-SeH. Cy-SeH coexists with its conjugate base, Cy=Se. One emits red fluorescence, and the other one emits green fluorescence. The response unit, -SeH, can trap Hg2+ via a Se-Hg antagonism reaction to afford an orange-emitting final product, Keto-Cy. The probe offers high selectivity and sensitivity toward O2â¢- and Hg2+. When applied for O2â¢- and Hg2+ detection in HEK 293 cells, the imaging results indicate that our probe can provide a combined response for O2â¢- and Hg2+ in real time and in situ. Flow cytometry anal. is well-consistent with the results from fluorescence imaging. When applied to image O2â¢- and Hg2+ in mice models, we find that Hg2+ dominantly accumulates in the kidney and induces a burst of O2â¢-. We confirm that chronic mercurialism can cause severe oxidative damage and renal fibrosis. HCy-SeH further provides a new information that, even when intracellular Hg2+ has been antagonized, the outbreak of O2â¢- caused by mercury poisoning still lasts.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®

        open URL

        Yu, L.; Ke, H. L.; Du, F. S.; Li, Z. C. Redox-responsive fluorescent polycarbonates based on selenide for chemotherapy of triple-negative breast cancer. Biomacromolecules. 2019, 20, 2809â 2820,  DOI: 10.1021/acs.biomac.9b00583
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        58
        Redox-Responsive Fluorescent Polycarbonates Based on Selenide for Chemotherapy of Triple-Negative Breast Cancer
        Yu, Li; Ke, He-Liang; Du, Fu-Sheng; Li, Zi-Chen
        Biomacromolecules (2019), 20 (7), 2809-2820CODEN: BOMAF6; ISSN:1525-7797. (American Chemical Society)
        Transient increase of reactive oxygen species (ROS) is vital for some physiol. processes, whereas the chronic and sustained high ROS level is usually implicated in the inflammatory diseases and cancers. Herein, we report the innovative redox-responsive theranostic micellar nanoparticles that are able to load anticancer drugs through coordination and hydrophobic interaction and to fluorescently monitor the intracellular redox status. The nanoparticles were formed by the amphiphilic block copolymers composed of a PEG segment and a selenide-contg. hydrophobic polycarbonate block with a small fraction of coumarin-based chromophore. Under the alternative redox stimulation that might be encountered in the physiol. process of some healthy cells, these nanoparticles underwent the reversible changes in size, morphol., and fluorescence intensity. With the assistance of small model compds., we clarified the chem. behind these changes, i.e., the redox triggered reversible transformation between selenide and selenoxide. Upon the monotonic oxidn. similar to the sustained high ROS level of cancer cells, the nanoparticles could be disrupted completely, which was accompanied by the drastic decrease in fluorescence. Cisplatin and paclitaxel were simultaneously coloaded in the nanoparticles with a moderate efficacy, and the coordination between selenide and platinum improved the stability of the drug-loaded nanoparticles against diln. The naked nanoparticles are cytocompatible, whereas the dual drug-loaded nanoparticles exhibited a concn. dependent and synergistic cytotoxicity to triple-neg. breast cancer (TNBC) cells. Of importance, the drug-loaded nanoparticles are much more toxic to TNBC cells than to normal cells due in part to ROS overprodn. in the former cell lines.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1MXhtFegtLjJ&md5=1079f561a82c5988193f3b5caabaac0b

        Probing the Formation of a Seleninic Acid in Living Cells by the Fluorescence Switching of a Glutathione Peroxidase Mimetic
        Ungati, Harinarayana; Govindaraj, Vijayakumar; Narayanan, Megha; Mugesh, Govindasamy
        Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2019), 58 (24), 8156-8160CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        Glutathione peroxidase (GPx) is a selenoenzyme that protects cells against oxidative damage. Although the formation of a seleninic acid (-SeO2H) by this enzyme during oxidative stress has been proposed, a selenic acid has not been identified in cells. Herein, we report that the formation of a seleninic acid can be monitored in living cells by using a redox-active ebselen analog with a naphthalimide fluorophore. The probe reacts with H2O2 to generate the highly fluorescent seleninic acid. The electron withdrawing nature of the -SeO2H moiety and strong SeÂ·Â·Â·O interactions, which prevent the photoinduced electron transfer, are responsible for the fluorescence.

Evaluation of Ebselen-azadioxatriangulenium as redox-sensitive fluorescent intracellular probe and as indicator within a planar redox optode. Dyes Pigm. 2020, 173, 107866,  DOI: 10.1016/j.dyepig.2019.107866
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        60
        Evaluation of Ebselen-azadioxatriangulenium as redox-sensitive fluorescent intracellular probe and as indicator within a planar redox optode
        Koren, Klaus; Gravesen Salinas, Nina Katharina; Santella, Marco; Mosshammer, Maria; Muller, Marie-Caroline; Dmitriev, Ruslan I.; Borisov, Sergey M.; Kuhl, Michael; Laursen, Bo W.
        Dyes and Pigments (2020), 173 (), 107866CODEN: DYPIDX; ISSN:0143-7208. (Elsevier Ltd.)
        Redox homeostasis is essential for cellular survival and is therefore tightly regulated. Visualizing changes in the local redox state is essential for detecting oxidative stress, esp. with the help of red, long emission lifetime probes. The authors synthesized a new reversible, redox-sensitive fluorescent probe, ebselen-azadioxatriangulenium (Ebselen-ADOTA), and characterized its potential use for intra- and extracellular redox sensing. The probe consists of a photostable triangulenium-based fluorophore (emission max. at 564 nm) modulated by a redox-active ebselen motif. The reduced form only shows around 1/10 of the emission intensity of the oxidized form. The Ebselen-ADOTA probe exhibited reversible oxidn. and redn. in soln. under extracellular conditions. In addn., Ebselen-ADOTA can visualize an increase in oxidative stress within anaerobic bacteria when exposing them to air, the probe did not readily respond to changes in the redox environment inside mammalian cells, probably due to unfavorable localization, aggregation or binding to cysteine contg. proteins. When incorporated inside a polymer matrix (hydrogel D4 mixed with poly(acrylic acid)), the probe showed a rapid and fully reversible response to redox changes, thus enabling the prepn. of a redox-sensitive optode.

        Unraveling peroxynitrite formation in biological systems
        Radi, R.; Peluffo, G.; Alvarez, M. N.; Naviliat, M.; Cayota, A.
        Free Radical Biology & Medicine (2001), 30 (5), 463-488CODEN: FRBMEH; ISSN:0891-5849. (Elsevier Science Inc.)
        A review with 200 refs. Peroxynitrite promotes oxidative damage and is implicated in the pathophysiol. of various diseases that involve accelerated rates of nitric oxide and superoxide formation. The unambiguous detection of peroxynitrite in biol. systems is, however, difficult due to the combination of a short biol. half-life, limited diffusion, multiple target mol. reactions, and participation of alternative oxidn./nitration pathways. In this review, the authors provide the conceptual framework and a comprehensive anal. of the current exptl. strategies that can serve to unequivocally define the existence and quantitation of peroxynitrite in biol. systems of different levels of organization and complexity.

      65. 65
        Ferrer-Sueta, G.; Radi, R. Chemical biology of peroxynitrite: Kinetics, diffusion, and radicals. ACS Chem. Biol. 2009, 4, 161â 177,  DOI: 10.1021/cb800279q
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        65
        Chemical Biology of Peroxynitrite: Kinetics, Diffusion, and Radicals
        Ferrer-Sueta, Gerardo; Radi, Rafael
        ACS Chemical Biology (2009), 4 (3), 161-177CODEN: ACBCCT; ISSN:1554-8929. (American Chemical Society)
        A review. Peroxynitrite is formed by the very fast reaction of nitric oxide and superoxide radicals, a reaction that kinetically competes with other routes that chem. consume or phys. sequester the reagents. It can behave either as an endogenous cytotoxin toward host tissues or a cytotoxic effector mol. against invading pathogens, depending on the cellular source and pathophysiol. setting. Peroxynitrite is in itself very reactive against a few specific targets that range from efficient detoxification systems, such as peroxiredoxins, to reactions eventually leading to enhanced radical formation (e.g., nitrogen dioxide and carbonate radicals), such as the reaction with carbon dioxide. Thus, the chem. biol. of peroxynitrite is dictated by the chem. kinetics of its formation and decay and by the diffusion across membranes of the species involved, including peroxynitrite itself. On the other hand, most durable traces of peroxynitrite passing (such as 3-nitrotyrosine) are derived from radicals formed from peroxynitrite by routes that represent extremely low-yield processes but that have potentially crit. biol. consequences. Here, we have reviewed the chem. kinetics of peroxynitrite as a biochem. transient species in order to est. its rates of formation and decay and then its steady-state concn. in different intra- or extracellular compartments, trying to provide a quant. basis for its reactivity; addnl., we have considered diffusion across membranes to locate its possible effects. Finally, we have assessed the most successful attempts to intercept peroxynitrite by pharmacol. intervention in their potential to increment the existing biol. defenses that routinely deal with this cytotoxin.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXislOisbg%253D&md5=ff2d50363797e63f00c0e5e9b5a6cbc8
        open URL
      66. 66
        Pacher, P.; Beckman, J. S.; Liaudet, L. Nitric oxide and peroxynitrite in health and disease. Physiol. Rev. 2007, 87, 315â 428,  DOI: 10.1152/physrev.00029.2006
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        66
        Nitric oxide and peroxynitrite in health and disease
        Pacher, Pal; Beckman, Joseph S.; Liaudet, Lucas
        Physiological Reviews (2007), 87 (1), 315-424CODEN: PHREA7; ISSN:0031-9333. (American Physiological Society)
        A review. The discovery that mammalian cells have the ability to synthesize the free radical nitric oxide (NO) has stimulated an extraordinary impetus for scientific research in all the fields of biol. and medicine. Since its early description as an endothelial-derived relaxing factor, NO has emerged as a fundamental signaling device regulating virtually every crit. cellular function, as well as a potent mediator of cellular damage in a wide range of conditions. Recent evidence indicates that most of the cytotoxicity attributed to NO is rather due to peroxynitrite, produced from the diffusion-controlled reaction between NO and another free radical, the superoxide anion. Peroxynitrite interacts with lipids, DNA, and proteins via direct oxidative reactions or via indirect, radical-mediated mechanisms. These reactions trigger cellular responses ranging from subtle modulations of cell signaling to overwhelming oxidative injury, committing cells to necrosis or apoptosis. In vivo, peroxynitrite generation represents a crucial pathogenic mechanism in conditions such as stroke, myocardial infarction, chronic heart failure, diabetes, circulatory shock, chronic inflammatory diseases, cancer, and neurodegenerative disorders. Hence, novel pharmacol. strategies aimed at removing peroxynitrite might represent powerful therapeutic tools in the future. Evidence supporting these novel roles of NO and peroxynitrite is presented in detail in this review.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2sXitVagsr8%253D&md5=43534aa55fe52c09a2c19d04e8a652dd
        open URL

        SzabÃ³, C.; Ischiropoulos, H.; Radi, R. Peroxynitrite: biochemistry, pathophysiology and development of therapeutics. Nat. Rev. Drug. Discovery 2007, 6, 662â 680,  DOI: 10.1038/nrd2222
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        67
        Peroxynitrite: biochemistry, pathophysiology and development of therapeutics
        Szabo, Csaba; Ischiropoulos, Harry; Radi, Rafael
        Nature Reviews Drug Discovery (2007), 6 (8), 662-680CODEN: NRDDAG; ISSN:1474-1776. (Nature Publishing Group)
        A review. Peroxynitrite - the product of the diffusion-controlled reaction of nitric oxide with superoxide radical - is a short-lived oxidant species that is a potent inducer of cell death. Conditions in which the reaction products of peroxynitrite have been detected and in which pharmacol. inhibition of its formation or its decompn. have been shown to be of benefit include vascular diseases, ischemia-reperfusion injury, circulatory shock, inflammation, pain and neurodegeneration. In this review, the authors first discuss the biochem. and pathophysiol. of peroxynitrite and then focus on pharmacol. strategies to attenuate the toxic effects of peroxynitrite. These include its catalytic redn. to nitrite and its isomerization to nitrate by metalloporphyrins, which have led to potential candidates for drug development for cardiovascular, inflammatory and neurodegenerative diseases.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®

        Beckman, J. S.; Beckman, T. W.; Chen, J.; Marshall, P. A.; Freeman, B. Apparent hydroxyl radical production by peroxynitrite: Implications for endothelial injury from nitric oxide and superoxide. A. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1990, 87, 1620â 1624,  DOI: 10.1073/pnas.87.4.1620

        68
        Apparent hydroxyl radical production by peroxynitrite: implications for endothelial injury from nitric oxide and superoxide
        Beckman, Joseph S.; Beckman, Tanya W.; Chen, Jun; Marshall, Patricia A.; Freeman, Bruce A.
        Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America (1990), 87 (4), 1620-4CODEN: PNASA6; ISSN:0027-8424.
        Peroxynitrite has a pKa of 7.49 at 37Â° and rapidly decomps. once protonated with a half-life of 1.9 s at pH 7.4. Peroxynitrite decompn. generates a strong oxidant with reactivity similar to hydroxyl radical, as assessed by the oxidn. of deoxyribose or DMSO. Product yields indicative of hydroxyl radical were 5.1 and 24.3%, resp., of added peroxynitrite. Product formation was not affected by the metal chelator diethyltriaminepentaacetic acid, suggesting that iron was not required to catalyze oxidn. In contrast, desferrioxamine was a potent, competitive inhibitor of peroxynitrite-initiated oxidn. because of a direct reaction between desferrioxamine and peroxynitrite rather than by iron chelation. Superoxide dismutase may protect vascular tissue stimulated to produce superoxide and NO under pathol. conditions by preventing the formation of peroxynitrite.

        Substrate-induced redox change of selenium in glutathione peroxidase studied by x-ray photoelectron spectroscopy
        Wendel, A.; Pilz, W.; Ladenstein, R.; Sawatzki, G.; Weser, U.
        Biochimica et Biophysica Acta, Enzymology (1975), 377 (1), 211-15CODEN: BBEZAD; ISSN:0924-1086.
        Glutathione peroxidase showed an x-ray photoelectron spectroscopy signal of the Se 3d (3/2, 5/2) electrons at 54.4 eV. After the addn. of the acceptor substrate, H2O2, a marked shift of this signal to a value of 58.0 eV was obsd. Upon subsequent treatment with the donor substrate, glutathione, this chem. shift was reversed and the original signal was obtained. These data demonstrate that the enzyme-bound Se moiety participates in the catalytic process. From the chem. shift obtained, it is concluded that the enzyme shuttles between a selenol or selenol deriv. in its reduced form and a seleninyl or selenonyl compd. in its oxidized form.

        Kinetic study of the reaction of ebselen with peroxynitrite
        Masumoto, Hiroshi; Kissner, Reinhard; Koppenol, Willem H.; Sies, Helmut
        FEBS Letters (1996), 398 (2,3), 179-182CODEN: FEBLAL; ISSN:0014-5793. (Elsevier)
        The second-order rate const. for the reaction of ebselen with peroxynitrite (ONOO-) is (2.0Â±0.1)Ã106 M-1 s-1 at pHâ¥8 and 25Â°, 3-4 orders of magnitude higher than the rate consts. obsd. for cysteine, ascorbate, or methionine. The activation energy is relatively low, 12.8 kJ/mol. This is the fastest reaction of peroxynitrite obsd. so far. It may allow Se-contg. compds. to play a novel role in the defense against peroxynitrite, one of the important reactive species generated during inflammatory processes.

        Sun, C.; Du, W.; Wang, P.; Wu, Y.; Wang, B.; Wang, J.; Xie, W. A novel mitochondria-targeted two-photon fluorescent probe for dynamic and reversible detection of the redox cycles between peroxynitrite and glutathione. Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun. 2017, 494, 518â 525,  DOI: 10.1016/j.bbrc.2017.10.123
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        73
        A novel mitochondria-targeted two-photon fluorescent probe for dynamic and reversible detection of the redox cycles between peroxynitrite and glutathione
        Sun, Chunlong; Du, Wen; Wang, Peng; Wu, Yang; Wang, Baoqin; Wang, Jun; Xie, Wenjun
        Biochemical and Biophysical Research Communications (2017), 494 (3-4), 518-525CODEN: BBRCA9; ISSN:0006-291X. (Elsevier B.V.)
        Redox homeostasis is important for maintenance of normal physiol. functions within cells. Redox state of cells is primarily a consequence of precise balance between levels of reducing equiv. and reactive oxygen species. Redox homeostasis between peroxynitrite (ONOO-) and glutathione (GSH) is closely assocd. with physiol. and pathol. processes, such as prolonged relaxation in vascular tissues and smooth muscle prepns., attenuation of hepatic necrosis, and activation of matrix metalloproteinase-2. We report a two-photon fluorescent probe (TP-Se) based on water-sol. carbazole-based compd., which integrates with org. selenium, to monitor changes in ONOO-/GSH levels in cells. This probe can reversibly respond to ONOO- and GSH and exhibits high selectivity, sensitivity, and mitochondrial targeting. The probe was successfully applied to visualize changes in redox cycles during ONOO- outbreak and antioxidant GSH repair in cells. The probe will lead to significant development on redox events involved in cellular redox regulation.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2sXhslChs77K&md5=a60334f4675b2de4090b5194ab23de56

      74. 74
        Winterbourn, C. C.; Hampton, M. B.; Livesey, J. H.; Kettle, A. J. Modeling the reactions of superoxide and myeloperoxidase in the neutrophil phagosome: implications for microbial killing. J. Biol. Chem. 2006, 281, 39860â 39869,  DOI: 10.1074/jbc.M605898200
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        74
        Modeling the Reactions of Superoxide and Myeloperoxidase in the Neutrophil Phagosome: Implications for Microbial Killing
        Winterbourn, Christine C.; Hampton, Mark B.; Livesey, John H.; Kettle, Anthony J.
        Journal of Biological Chemistry (2006), 281 (52), 39860-39869CODEN: JBCHA3; ISSN:0021-9258. (American Society for Biochemistry and Molecular Biology)
        Neutrophils kill bacteria by ingesting them into phagosomes where superoxide and cytoplasmic granule constituents, including myeloperoxidase, are released. Myeloperoxidase converts chloride and hydrogen peroxide to hypochlorous acid (HOCl), which is strongly microbicidal. However, the role of oxidants in killing and the species responsible are poorly understood and the subject of current debate. To assess what oxidative mechanisms are likely to operate in the narrow confines of the phagosome, the authors have used a kinetic model to examine the fate of superoxide and its interactions with myeloperoxidase. Known rate consts. for reactions of myeloperoxidase were used and substrate concns. estd. from neutrophil morphol. In the model, superoxide is generated at several mM/s. Most react with myeloperoxidase, which is present at millimolar concns., and rapidly convert the enzyme to compd. III. Compd. III turnover by superoxide is essential to maintain enzyme activity. Superoxide stabilizes at â¼25 Î¼M and hydrogen peroxide in the low micromolar range. HOCl prodn. is efficient if there is adequate chloride supply, but further knowledge on chloride concns. and transport mechanisms is needed to assess whether this is the case. Low myeloperoxidase concns. also limit HOCl prodn. by allowing more hydrogen peroxide to escape from the phagosome. In the absence of myeloperoxidase, superoxide increases to >100 Î¼M but hydrogen peroxide to only â¼30 Î¼M. Most of the HOCl reacts with released granule proteins before reaching the bacterium, and chloramine products may be effectors of its antimicrobial activity. Hydroxyl radicals should form only after all susceptible protein targets are consumed.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD28XhtlCrtrbL&md5=1525df6734b4a8719d6f7c7b592ac498
        open URL
      75. 75
        Yap, Y. W.; Whiteman, M.; Cheung, N. S. Chlorinative stress: an under appreciated mediator of neurodegeneration?. Cell Signal. 2007, 19, 219â 228,  DOI: 10.1016/j.cellsig.2006.06.013
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        75
        Chlorinative stress: an under appreciated mediator of neurodegeneration?
        Yap, Yann Wan; Whiteman, Matthew; Cheung, Nam Sang
        Cellular Signalling (2007), 19 (2), 219-228CODEN: CESIEY; ISSN:0898-6568. (Elsevier B.V.)
        A review. Oxidative stress has been implicated as playing a role in neurodegenerative disorders, such as ischemic stroke, Alzheimer's, Huntington's, and Parkinson's disease. Persuasive evidences have shown that microglial-mediated oxidative stress contributes significantly to cell loss and accompanying cognitive decline characteristic of the diseases. Based on the facts that (i) levels of catalytically active myeloperoxidase are elevated in diseased brains and (ii) myeloperoxidase polymorphism is assocd. with the risk of developing neurodegenerative disorders, HOCl as a major oxidant produced by activated phagocytes in the presence of myeloperoxidase is therefore suggested to be involved in neurodegeneration. Its assocn. with neurodegeneration is further showed by elevated level of 3-chlorotyrosine (bio-marker of HOCl in vivo) in affected brain regions as well as HOCl scavenging ability of neuroprotectants, desferrioxamine and uric acid. In this review, we will summary the current understanding concerning the assocn. of HOCl and neuronal cell death where prodn. of HOCl will lead to further formation of reactive nitrogen and oxygen species. In addn., HOCl also causes tissue destruction and cellular damage leading cell death.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2sXhsFGhtw%253D%253D&md5=b23c8f92a2c33f33b490003317f7f09b
        open URL
      76. 76
        Steinbeck, M. J.; Nesti, L. J.; Sharkey, P. F.; Parvizi, J. Myeloperoxidase and chlorinated peptides in osteoarthritis: potential biomarkers of the disease. J. Orthop. Res. 2007, 25, 1128â 1135,  DOI: 10.1002/jor.20400
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        76
        Myeloperoxidase and chlorinated peptides in osteoarthritis: potential biomarkers of the disease
        Steinbeck, Marla J.; Nesti, Leon J.; Sharkey, Peter F.; Parvizi, Javad
        Journal of Orthopaedic Research (2007), 25 (9), 1128-1135CODEN: JOREDR; ISSN:0736-0266. (John Wiley & Sons, Inc.)
        Osteoarthritis (OA) is a disabling condition in which multiple initiating events or conditions (heritable and nonheritable) result in eventual loss of articular cartilage. However, the etiol. of OA remains poorly understood, and diagnosis of early disease is difficult due to the lack of specific identifiers. Recent literature suggests that a series of inflammatory processes may be involved in initiating and propagating OA. We hypothesized that products of neutrophils and macrophages, namely myeloperoxidase (MPO), a specific enzyme responsible for the prodn. of both highly reactive hypochlorous acid (HOCl) and chlorine gas (Cl2) and chlorinated peptides, may be present in the synovial fluid of patients with OA. We examd. the synovial fluid from 30 patients to identify and profile the presence of MPO. We divided the samples into three groups using radiog. and clin. assessment: (1) control, patients with acute knee injury with no history of OA and no radiog. evidence of OA; (2) early OA, patients with a mild OA based on radiographs; and (3) late OA, patients with a longstanding history of OA and with radiog. evidence of complete joint loss. Patients with early OA demonstrated significantly elevated levels of MPO. We also demonstrated the presence of HOCl and Cl2 modified proteins (Cl-peptides) in early OA synovial fluid samples by liq. chromatog. and mass spectrometry. Patients in the control and advanced OA groups demonstrated little elevation in MPO levels and Cl-peptides were undetectable. These results indicate that MPO and Cl-peptides may serve as diagnostic markers for the detection of early OA.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2sXhtVCqsLrF&md5=6140c5dffe60dfd2eba174978cb2fb37
        open URL
      77. 77
        Pattison, D. I.; Davies, M. J. Evidence for Rapid Inter- and Intramolecular Chlorine Transfer Reactions of Histamine and Carnosine Chloramines: Implications for the Prevention of Hypochlorous-Acid-Mediated Damage. Biochemistry 2006, 45, 8152â 8162,  DOI: 10.1021/bi060348s
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        77
        Evidence for Rapid Inter- and Intramolecular Chlorine Transfer Reactions of Histamine and Carnosine Chloramines: Implications for the Prevention of Hypochlorous-Acid-Mediated Damage
        Pattison, David I.; Davies, Michael J.
        Biochemistry (2006), 45 (26), 8152-8162CODEN: BICHAW; ISSN:0006-2960. (American Chemical Society)
        Hypochlorous acid (HOCl) is a powerful oxidant generated from H2O2 and Cl- by the heme enzyme myeloperoxidase, which is released from activated leukocytes. HOCl possesses potent antibacterial properties, but excessive prodn. can lead to host tissue damage that is implicated in a wide range of human diseases (e.g., atherosclerosis). Histamine and carnosine have been proposed as protective agents against such damage. However, as recent studies have shown that histidine-contg. compds. readily form imidazole chloramines that can rapidly chlorinate other targets, it was hypothesized that similar reactions may occur with histamine and carnosine, leading to propagation, rather than prevention, of HOCl-mediated damage. In this study, the reactions of HOCl with histamine, histidine, carnosine, and other compds. contg. imidazole and free amine sites were examd. In all cases, rapid formation (k, 1.6 Ã 105 M-1 s-1) of imidazole chloramines was obsd., followed by chlorine transfer to yield more stable, primary chloramines (R-NHCl). The rates of most of these secondary reactions are dependent upon substrate concns., consistent with intermol. mechanisms (k, 103-104 M-1 s-1). However, for carnosine, the imidazole chloramine transfer rates are independent of the concn., indicative of intramol. processes (k, 0.6 s-1). High-performance liq. chromatog. studies show that in all cases the resultant R-NHCl species can slowly chlorinate N-Î±-acetyl-Tyr. Thus, the current data indicate that the chloramines formed on the imidazole and free amine groups of these compds. can oxidize other target mols. but with limited efficiency, suggesting that histamine and particularly carnosine may be able to limit HOCl-mediated oxidn. in vivo.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD28Xlt1yqtrY%253D&md5=cb1de990baf7d54288910fb47ddba3b2
        open URL

        Pattison, I.; Davies, M. J. Absolute rate constants for the reaction of hypochlorous acid with protein side chains and peptide bonds. Chem. Res. Toxicol. 2001, 14, 1453â 1464,  DOI: 10.1021/tx0155451
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        78
        Absolute rate constants for the reaction of hypochlorous acid with protein side chains and peptide bonds
        Pattison, David I.; Davies, Michael J.
        Chemical Research in Toxicology (2001), 14 (10), 1453-1464CODEN: CRTOEC; ISSN:0893-228X. (American Chemical Society)
        Hypochlorous acid (HOCl) is a potent oxidant, which is produced in vivo by activated phagocytes. This compd. is an important antibacterial agent, but excessive or misplaced prodn. has been implicated in a no. of human diseases, including atherosclerosis, arthritis, and some cancers. Proteins are major targets for this oxidant, and such reaction results in side-chain modification, backbone fragmentation, and crosslinking. Despite a wealth of qual. data for such reactions, little abs. kinetic data is available to rationalize the in vitro and in vivo data. In this study, abs. second-order rate consts. for the reactions of HOCl with protein side chains, model compds., and backbone amide (peptide) bonds have been detd. at physiol. pH values. The reactivity of HOCl with potential reactive sites in proteins is summarized by the series: Met (3.8 Ã 107 M-1 s-1) > Cys (3.0 Ã 107 M-1 s-1) Â» cystine (1.6 Ã 105 M-1 s-1) â His (1.0 Ã 105 M-1 s-1) â Î±-amino (1.0 Ã 105 M-1 s-1) > Trp (1.1 Ã 104 M-1 s-1) > Lys (5.0 Ã 103 M-1 s-1) Â» Tyr (44 M-1 s-1) â Arg (26 M-1 s-1) > backbone amides (10-10-3 M-1 s-1) > Gln (0.03 M-1 s-1) â Asn (0.03 M-1 s-1). The rate consts. for reaction of HOCl with backbone amides (peptide bonds) vary by 4 orders of magnitude with uncharged peptide bonds reacting more readily with HOCl than those in a charged environment. These kinetic parameters have been used in computer modeling of the reactions of HOCl with human serum albumin, apolipoprotein-A1 and free amino acids in plasma at different molar excesses. These models are useful tools for predicting, and reconciling, exptl. data obtained in HOCl-induced oxidns. and allow estns. to be made as to the flux of HOCl to which proteins are exposed in vivo.

        Development of a selenide-based fluorescent probe for imaging hypochlorous acid in lysosomes
        Qu, Zongjin; Ding, Junxia; Zhao, Meiyu; Li, Peng
        Journal of Photochemistry and Photobiology, A: Chemistry (2015), 299 (), 1-8CODEN: JPPCEJ; ISSN:1010-6030. (Elsevier B.V.)
        The development of fluorescent probes for hypochlorous acid (HOCl) has received intense attention because of the biol. significance of HOCl. In this work, a novel fluorescent probe based on a selenide switch for the detection of HOCl in lysosomes has been designed and synthesized on a 1,8-naphthalimide scaffold. The probe exhibited a high selectivity for HOCl over various reactive oxygen species (ROS) with a fast response and a large fluorescence enhancement in aq. media. Confocal microscopy imaging of living cells indicated that the probe was able to accumulate in lysosomes and was successfully applied to imaging exogenous HOCl in living cells. Attempts of using Lyso-NI-Se to image HOCl in stimulated RAW264.7 cells failed, probably due to the absence of endogenous HOCl in lysosomes or the undesirable detection limit.

        Enhanced Fluorescence Turn-on Imaging of Hypochlorous Acid in Living Immune and Cancer Cells
        Mulay, Sandip V.; Choi, Minsuk; Jang, Yoon Jeong; Kim, Youngsam; Jon, Sangyong; Churchill, David G.
        Chemistry - A European Journal (2016), 22 (28), 9642-9648CODEN: CEUJED; ISSN:0947-6539. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        Two closely related Ph selenyl based boron-dipyrromethene (BODIPY) turn-on fluorescent probes for the detection of hypochlorous acid (HOCl) were synthesized for studies in chem. biol.; emission intensity is modulated by a photoinduced electron-transfer (PET) process. Probe 2 intrinsically shows a negligible background signal; however, after reaction with HOCl, chem. oxidn. of selenium forecloses the PET process, which evokes a significant increase in fluorescence intensity. The fluorescence intensity of probes 1 and 2 with HOCl involves an â¼18 and â¼50-fold enhancement compared with the resp. responses from other reactive oxygen/nitrogen species (ROS/RNS) and low detection limits (30.9 nM for 1 and 4.5 nM for 2). Both probes show a very fast response with HOCl; emission intensity reached a max. within 1 s. These probes show high selectivity for HOCl, as confirmed by confocal microscopy imaging when testing with RAW264.7 and MCF-7 cells.

        Substituent Effects in BODIPY in Live Cell Imaging
        Mulay, Sandip V.; Yudhistira, Tesla; Choi, Minsuk; Kim, Youngsam; Kim, Jinjoo; Jang, Yoon Jeong; Jon, Sangyong; Churchill, David G.
        Chemistry - An Asian Journal (2016), 11 (24), 3598-3605CODEN: CAAJBI; ISSN:1861-4728. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        Small-mol. organoselenium-based fluorescent probes possess great capacity in understanding biol. processes through the detection of various analytes such as reactive oxygen/nitrogen species (ROS/RNS), biothiols (cysteine, homocysteine and glutathione), lipid droplets, etc. Herein, we present how substituents on the BODIPY system play a significant part in the detection of biol. important analytes for in vitro conditions and live cell imaging studies. The fluorescence of the probe was quenched by 2-chloro and 6-Ph selenium groups; the probe shows high selectivity with NaOCl among other ROS/RNS, and gives a turn-on response. The max. fluorescence intensity is attained within â1-2 min with a low detection limit (19.6 nM), and shows a â110-fold fluorescence enhancement compared to signals generated for other ROS/RNS. Surprisingly, in live cell expts., the probe specifically located and accumulated in lipid droplets, and showed a fluorescence turn-on response. We believe this turn-on response occurred because of aggregation-induced emission (AIE), which surprisingly occurred only by introducing one lipophilic mesityl group at the meso position of the BODIPY.

        Overriding Phthalate Decomposition When Exploring Mycophenolic Acid Intermediates as Selenium-Based ROS Biological Probes
        Halle, Mahesh B.; Yudhistira, Tesla; Lee, Kyung Jin; Choi, Jae Hyuck; Kim, Youngsam; Park, Hee-Sung; Churchill, David G.
        ACS Omega (2018), 3 (10), 13474-13483CODEN: ACSODF; ISSN:2470-1343. (American Chemical Society)
        Hypochlorous (OCl-) acid is the most well-known bacterial oxidant to be produced by neutrophils. Excess amts. of OCl- can cause various disorders in living systems. Herein, the authors have designed, synthesized, and characterized two novel organoselenium-based target mols. (Probe-1 and Probe-OCl) based on a synthetic intermediate of mycophenolic acid (MPA) for the aq. detection of OCl-. Probe 1 has been recently reported (Org. Lett., 2018, 20, 3557-3561); both probes show immediate "turn on" fluorescence (< 1 s) upon the addn. of OCl-, display an increase in fluorescence quantum yield (3.7-fold in Probe-1 and 11.6-fold in Probe-OCl) and are completely sol. in aq. media without the help of any cosolvent. However, a decrease in "turn-on" intensity with the oxidized version of Probe-1 in cell assays due to the anhydride/phthalate functionality suggests probe degrdn. occurs based on hydrolytic action (probe degrdn. half-life of â¼1500 s at 15 Î¼M of Probe-1 and 150 Î¼M OCl). Thus, the change of "anhydride" to "methylamide" begets Probe-OCl which possesses more stability without sacrificing its water soly. properties and responses at short times. Further studies suggest that the Probe-OCl is highly stable within physiol. pH (pH = 7.4). Surprisingly, in live cell expts. involving U-2OS cells and HeLa cells, Probe-OCl accumulated and aggregated in lipid droplets (LDs) and gives a "turn-on" fluorescence response. MTT assays confirmed that Probe-OCl is not toxic. Cuvette aggregation studies were also performed (THF/H2O) to demonstrate aggregation-induced fluorescence at longer times. The current hypothesis is that the "turn-on" fluorescence effect is caused by the aggregation induced emission (AIE) mechanism available for Probe-OCl. In this case, in tandem the authors reanalyzed the Mes-BOD-SePh deriv. as well to compare and contrast cell localization as imaged by confocal microscopy; fluorescence emission occurs in the absence of, or prior to, Se oxidn.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®

        Utilizing the oxidn./elimination tandem reaction of the Î±-phenylseleno carbonyl moiety, a two-photon fluorescent probe for ratiometric visualization of hypochlorous acid was developed. Its superior sensing performance and practical applications were well demonstrated.

        A naphthalimide based fast and selective fluorescent probe for hypochlorous acid/hypochlorite and its application for bioimaging
        Lv, Xin; Yuan, Xia; Wang, Yue; Guo, Wei
        New Journal of Chemistry (2018), 42 (18), 15105-15110CODEN: NJCHE5; ISSN:1144-0546. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        A reversible and mitochondria targetable fluorescent probe (Nap-Se) bearing 1,8-naphthalimide and a selenomorpholine fragment was designed and synthesized. The probe showed a highly selective, sensitive and fast response (<2 s) toward hypochlorous acid/hypochlorite in phosphate buffer saline soln. Cell imaging studies confirmed that probe Nap-Se was specifically localized in mitochondria of living cells and could be used to monitor the levels of endogenous and exogenous HClO/ClO- in RAW264.7 cells.

        Gale, P. A. Anion and ion-pair receptor chemistry: highlights from 2000 and 2001. Coord. Chem. Rev. 2003, 240, 191â 221,  DOI: 10.1016/S0010-8545(02)00258-8
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        90
        Anion and ion-pair receptor chemistry: highlights from 2000 and 2001
        Gale, Philip A.
        Coordination Chemistry Reviews (2003), 240 (1-2), 191-221CODEN: CCHRAM; ISSN:0010-8545. (Elsevier Science B.V.)
        A review. This review article highlights advances made in abiotic anion coordination chem. in 2000 and 2001. The structure of this review is that similar to the previous reviews in this series that covered 1997, 1998 and 1999. The review also includes examples of ion-pair receptors. The 1st section examines anion receptors that do not contain metal ions. This is followed by a review of metal contg. anion receptors in which the metal can function as: (i) a coordination site for the anion; (ii) an agent withdrawing electron d. from the receptor; (iii) an organizational element in the receptor; (iv) a sensor; and (v) a co-bound guest in ion-pair receptor. Examples of the role of anions in directing the self-assembly of complex mol. architectures are presented in the final section.

        Martinez-Manez, R.; Sancenon, F. Fluorogenic and chromogenic chemosensors and reagents for anions. Chem. Rev. 2003, 103, 4419â 4476,  DOI: 10.1021/cr010421e
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        92
        Fluorogenic and Chromogenic Chemosensors and Reagents for Anions
        Martinez-Manez, Ramon; Sancenon, Felix
        Chemical Reviews (Washington, DC, United States) (2003), 103 (11), 4419-4476CODEN: CHREAY; ISSN:0009-2665. (American Chemical Society)
        A review. This review deals with the use of fluorogenic and chromogenic reagents for anions sensing. In this sense, it is remarkable that there are relatively few examples on anion sensing when compared with the literature devoted to anion recognition or when compared to cation sensing. However, the no. of papers on anion sensing has grown considerably. The present review is a comprehensive anal. about signaling of small anions using changes in fluorescence, luminescence, or color (no changes in fluorescence or color using anionic macromols. such as DNA are included) and will point out how the use of relatively simple mols. is leading to the development of new systems for the selective sensing of target anionic guests. These advances suggest that it would be possible soon to have selective reagents for screening a wide range of anions of environmental, biol., and medical importance. Anion signaling using fluorescence or color changes can also be obsd. using irreversible reactions. Here, the term chemosensor should not strictly be applied and terms such as reagents, reactants, or chemodosimeters should be used. Despite their irreversible nature, recent advances in the area of chemodosimeters for anions also were included in this review.
